review_preview: (In case there is any confusion, this is a review of the restaurant La Paloma, Calle Jorge Juan 39, Madrid.)We went to La Paloma primarily to try their organ meats and other unusual dishes. This is a normal upscale restaurant in the upscale district...
review_full: (In case there is any confusion, this is a review of the restaurant La Paloma, Calle Jorge Juan 39, Madrid.) We went to La Paloma primarily to try their organ meats and other unusual dishes. This is a normal upscale restaurant in the upscale district of Salamanca. It by no means specializes in organ meats, but the chef does usually have a few such items on the menu. Our waiter was very knowledgeable and helped us choose from three or four different offerings. We started with something a little different but still unusual: erizos (sea urchin) grated and served in sea urchin shells along with a quail egg. They were delicious and tasting of the sea. One of our main courses was the manitos de cerdo (pig’s feet), which must have been somewhat labor-intensive to prepare. All the bones were removed from the feet (I did find a very small one) and then the remaining “meat” was shaped into a patty and sautéed and served with a mustard and truffle sauce. This was an elegant presentation and far from the typical image of “pig’s feet”. Our other second course was the mollejas de ternera (veal sweetbreads), braised with vegetables, pretty much the way they would be prepared in France. Our wine was a bottle of the house Rioja. Like many restaurants in Madrid, La Paloma offers half portions, a necessary corrective to the Spanish custom of serving huge amounts of food. If you are not a fan of organ meats, you should read other reviews and find out what else La Paloma offers. This is an excellent high-end restaurant with a broad selection of meats, seafood, and vegetables.

review_preview: Okay, without exaggerating, this was the most flavorful thing I ate on my 15 day trip around Spain and Portugal. First, the list of allergies I have honestly sends waiters into a deep depression as they try to work with the kitchen to find me...
review_full: Okay, without exaggerating, this was the most flavorful thing I ate on my 15 day trip around Spain and Portugal. First, the list of allergies I have honestly sends waiters into a deep depression as they try to work with the kitchen to find me something to eat! Not here, I handed the waiter my card and he said, and I quote "that's all?" Turns out that I was only able to eat one item on the menu...but it was divine and I am still thinking about it a week later! It was the Duck Confit with lentils....absolutely amazing. So good, in fact, I ordered a second. I could go on for days about the balance of flavors and the cute little cast iron pot it was served in...just great.  My friend had several other items and enjoyed them as well (I honestly can't recall what they were as I was having a serious moment with my own food). Super friendly staff, good selection of tapas for all sorts of allergies (they have ingredient cards as well so you can check for yourself) and the place was old but clean (including the bathrooms which I place very high on my list of restaurant criteria). So, if you decide to stop here, I doubt you'll be disappointed!

We looked at the menu and ordered a lovely tomato mozzarella salad. Overall a great experience!

review_full: I came here after looking up gluten free friendly places in Madrid. A small, unassuming place, there is a bar area upstairs and then some seating downstairs, which is where we sat. Our waitress spoke perfect English and I was told apart from one or two dishes (from a long list), all could be gluten free - hooray! My boyfriend and I shared several dishes and we were stuffed. I wanted to try as many as I could, but the portion sizes were generous. The dishes were really beautifully presented and very tasty. We were also given a free little appetiser to start off. Worth visiting, whether gluten free or not for good quality, and more interesting tapas.

Upstairs there is a small bar. Basically you can get almost every dish gluten free in this restaurant, and that made my wife fly. While we shared the dishes , also I had a taste of these gluten free portions and  really enjoyed. We took kind of few tapas to start with like caprese - salad, anchovies toast, white shrimps carpaccio and chicken as a main course. None of these was a disappointment - on the contrary we really enjoyed. The lady who was our waiter was really busy but she had always time when we had something to ask.  Absolute must who is looking for gluten free options, or just great tapas! and very affordable.

I settled on a full portion of Langoustine Ravioli, and a half portion of stuffed Duck, mushroom and onion canneloni. Both were very tasty, I also had a chocolate souffle, probably one item too many. there is a constant flow of little items between courses. You will get an amuse bouche, and a plate of bites at the end. If you are unsure about a dessert, probably give it a miss, you will get a plate of chocolates, tuiles and sweets to finish. The head waiter was very helpful, with suggestions, which I declined, as I was only after a light mid-day meal. All in all very hospitable to this solo traveller. Pleasant surroundings inside, the terrace is on a quieter road than most.

title_review: First Class Cuisine in an Elegant and Stylish Ambience
review_preview: During a recent lengthy stay in Madrid we had lunch in La Paloma once and dinner twice. If we had discovered it sooner we would have gone more often and will certainly go again.Located in the Goya area of Salamanca in Madrid, this is...
review_full: During a recent lengthy stay in Madrid we had lunch in La Paloma once and dinner twice. If we had discovered it sooner we would have gone more often and will certainly go again. Located in the Goya area of Salamanca in Madrid, this is an elegant and stylish restaurant - somewhat formal with a very professional level of service. We found the menu interesting and varied - on our visits supplemented by a few "specials". The wine list offered a wide range of Spanish wines - suiting most tastes and pockets. As another reviewer has mentioned "half servings" are offered for those with a smaller appetite. Also as noted by another reviewer, on our visits most other customers were fairly formally dressed or at least in smart casual attire. This is not an inexpensive restaurant: our dinners of three courses (no "half servings"), wine, coffee and armagnac were around 75€. However, given the quality of the produce used, the high standard of cooking, the level of service and the ambience, we believed it was worth every euro spent. We have already recommended La Paloma to friends travelling to Madrid and will continue to do so. It deserves all the favourable reviews it has received and I am sure it will receive more.

He was very nice even though he was the only one serving and tending bar (short-staffed that night). Highly recommend.

review_preview: I visited this lovely little bar with my boyfriend a couple of days ago. We were greeted warmly, and had dinner downstairs - it had a cosy atmosphere and we loved the newspaper wallpaper and other decor.Food - we had curry chicken with rice,...
review_full: I visited this lovely little bar with my boyfriend a couple of days ago. We were greeted warmly, and had dinner downstairs - it had a cosy atmosphere and we loved the newspaper wallpaper and other decor. Food - we had curry chicken with rice, and red pepper stuffed with cheese with bechamel sauce. Both were very tasty and good value. We were also given a free starter of potato salad with our drinks. Wine - we asked for a dry white wine and were served a delicious spanish variety (can't remember the name). Service - impeccable! The lovely waitress was very friendly, attentive and helpful, even though we speak little Spanish. In fact, we returned again the following night for a few drinks and were welcomed again - on this occasion we did not order food, but we were given two sets of complimentary tapas with our wine which was lovely. Ignore any poor reviews, this place is the perfect stop for great service and tasty yet affordable food and wine.

title_review: Amazing food, great service, and safe for Celiacs!
review_preview: We visited Taberna La Concha last week while in Spain on holiday. I have celiac disease, and I read reviews online that said that Taberna La Concha had a gluten free menu. When we arrived, we were first seated and had our order taken by...
review_full: We visited Taberna La Concha last week while in Spain on holiday. I have celiac disease, and I read reviews online that said that Taberna La Concha had a gluten free menu. When we arrived, we were first seated and had our order taken by (I think) the bartender, who wasn’t unfriendly but also wasn’t the friendliest. However, he was super understanding of gluten free and we felt confident ordering.  Halfway through the meal a woman (the owner or chef maybe) started serving us, and she was fabulous! She recommended a new tapas dish to their menu, which was amazing, and even brought out chocolates when we said we were too full for a whole dessert.  We ordered five tapas and all were absolutely delicious - our favorite was the new plate, the Migas. It was INCREDIBLE! The cheeses, meats, and toasts that we ordered were also wonderful. I didn’t feel sick at all after eating here, so they clearly know what they are doing with gluten free food. Highly recommend!!! Great meal all around and some of the best service we had in Madrid.

title_review: If we lived in Madrid, we would be regulars
review_preview: A perfect place to hang out after a long day. Very good wines (many of them also by the glass), perfect tapas, very attentive service, great atmosphere, all this crammed in a tiny space. Lonesome no more, as Kurt Vonnegut would say. Definitely try 'Salmorejo'...
review_full: A perfect place to hang out after a long day. Very good wines (many of them also by the glass), perfect tapas, very attentive service, great atmosphere, all this crammed in a tiny space. Lonesome no more, as Kurt Vonnegut would say. Definitely try 'Salmorejo' and their exquisite 'Tosta de gambas' from the dishes. From the wine menu we were offered 'Vega Ibor Garnacha 2017' and 'Txakoli Primo Zarautz 2017' the first time we went there (yes, we did return) and 'Juan Gil Moscato Dry 2017', Bertola Cat Wine Monastrell-Shiraz 2017', as well as 'Peique Menzia Bierzo 2015' and 'Destiempo Verdejo 2017' the second time. We did not regret any of them. (Though not relevant for us, they also serve gluten-free dishes and drinks.)

title_review: Love it, must go if you're a foodie
review_preview: We always spend a considerably amount of time researching places to eat for our vacations. We love Spanish food and we always want to make the most out of our time in Spain. This place is very casual, however, the chef does an amazing job...
review_full: We always spend a considerably amount of time researching places to eat for our vacations. We love Spanish food and we always want to make the most out of our time in Spain. This place is very casual, however, the chef does an amazing job by using traditional ingredients but giving them a more modern/ gourmet twist. This place is extremely affordable, the quality of the food is excellent. I will definitely go back next time we are in Madrid. If you are looking for something different from the "traditional tapas places" you must go to this place. The young chef is so proud and puts so much love into what he makes that he refused to take a tip (we left a very good tip anyway, he deserved it his food was amazing).

review_preview: I didn't expect much from this place. It looked like every other touristic place in that area. What attracted my attention was a selection of paellas they had, declaration they're made on the spot just for you and their size (for 1 person). I ate...
review_full: I didn't expect much from this place. It looked like every other touristic place in that area. What attracted my attention was a selection of paellas they had, declaration they're made on the spot just for you and their size (for 1 person). I ate there with my wife and first of all we were charmed by extremely kind and helpful staff. The paella came with mojito in an offer for 12 EUR which is a complete bargain (although the size of served mojito was something one could expect of a free mojito)! We also had pizza which was rich in flavor, well baked and generally fine. Sangria was very tasty. The place itself, in my opinion, lacks an idea for the theme. The interior is rather dark, dull, and quite uninteresting and not really cozy. However, our overall experience was very good and we would go back there.

review_preview: We walked into this restaurant in the early evening and were quickly seated by the most friendly and gracious server, with a broad smile on her face. As we got talking, we learned that she and her sister, the manager, were Venezuelan, so a lively...
review_full: We walked into this restaurant in the early evening and were quickly seated by the most friendly and gracious server, with a broad smile on her face. As we got talking, we learned that she and her sister, the manager, were Venezuelan, so a lively discussion ensued. The menu has many tapas options that can be ordered in small portions of five items or individually for a larger plate. We instead ordered the meal from the dinner side of the menu, that features paella. Our server showed us all the items on an I-pad that greatly helped us to make our choice. On her advice, my husband ordered the "peeled"' seafood paella and said that it was the best paella he had ever had. I ordered the pasta tagliatelle with beef in a light broth. Sensational! From a decent list of wines, again on recommendation, we enjoyed a regional red. By the time our mains had arrived, the place was filling up and when we left, it was full. We returned the following day for tapas, the plate portions of three selections: pork skewers, stuffed mushrooms,and ham croquettes that we shared.This was followed by, of course, the "peeled paella." Greeted as long lost friends and pleased that we returned, we can't say enough about the hospitality of this friendly place and the quality of the culinary offerings.

The ice cream bon bon at the end of the meal helped satisfy my chocolate craving.

title_review: Excellent, authentic tapas (full of Spanish people)with brilliant service from a generous owner who speaks English.
review_preview: Visited this tapas bar after googling, and I loved it.Totally genuine taps bar. I was there at lunchtime on a Monday and I only heard Spanish spoken.  Not a tourist in sight (apart from me).The owner was friendly, speaks perfect English and helped...
review_full: Visited this tapas bar after googling, and I loved it. Totally genuine taps bar. I was there at lunchtime on a Monday and I only heard Spanish spoken. Not a tourist in sight (apart from me). The owner was friendly, speaks perfect English and helped me decide what to eat, primarily by talking about lots of dishes that weren't on the blackboard menu. I had meatballs and chicken curry, washed down with Rioja. The meatballs were perfect and the sauce was delicious (the generous bread serving helped to do this). I chose the curry as another website I saw when googling claimed it "the best ever". I'm not sure about this but it was very, very good. Chicken curry with green beans and mashed potato - weird combination for us English but very good nonetheless. If you want traditional, non touristy, good value tapas then please go here. It's not comfortable or luxurious but it's genuine and real. And as I have said, I loved it!

review_preview: Enjoy exceptional service and delicious food in this beautiful restaurant!  The staff were very professional and polite and they made us feel welcome and special.  It's worth the splurge if you're a foodie!!We didn't have the tasting menu, but instead ordered 2 appetizers, 1...
review_full: Enjoy exceptional service and delicious food in this beautiful restaurant! The staff were very professional and polite and they made us feel welcome and special. It's worth the splurge if you're a foodie!! We didn't have the tasting menu, but instead ordered 2 appetizers, 1 entree and 1 dessert each. Personally I think this is the way to go! We got to try 6 different things plus all of the little tasty extras they bring you! Typically with tasting menus you only get a bite of each item, so ordering off the regular menu gave us a chance to taste a number of different things properly. Unique food combinations with interesting textures and twists kept this meal intriguing. They started with a delicious fizzy mojito that was unlike anything we've ever had before! Some things were a little odd, but it all tasted yummy. Some examples include: little morsels that looked like olives and had the flavour of olives, but was the texture of sponge toffee (for lack of a better description). There were also emulsified ham and cheese croquettes and olive oil that had been whipped into a butter like texture and served in a mini toothpaste tube with freshly baked breads- totally yummy! Going from memory there is no way I could describe the food and do it justice. Just know that they are extremely creative and really think about food flavours and textures! If you're a meat and potatoes kind of person you can give this restaurant a miss, but if you are foodies like us and love to try the best and most creative food in town then La Terraza del Casino de Madrid is the place to go! One quick thing...it's very difficult to get a reservation! We called 2 months in advance and couldn't get in. However, any top notch hotel should be able to get you in with a phone call. We stayed at the Urban (see my review) and the concierge was extremely helpful.

review_preview: My husband and I enjoyed dinner at this wonderful establishment in September 2009, and feel it rates up there with any 3-starred Michelin restaurant in the USA.  After 20 courses of little bites masquerading as things they are not, your stomach and spirit will be...
review_full: My husband and I enjoyed dinner at this wonderful establishment in September 2009, and feel it rates up there with any 3-starred Michelin restaurant in the USA. After 20 courses of little bites masquerading as things they are not, your stomach and spirit will be filled with joy and pleasure. When I think back on our dinner, my mouth waters and my heart aches at the thought that I have to fly so far to eat there again. Service is impeccable - warm, professional, engaging, not stuffy, patient with our horrid Spanish Ambience - lovely and decadent from floor to ceiling Food - what can I say that hasn't already been said in other reviews? This is really an experience! The chef is a master of disguise and a true scientist. Yes, this may be more food science than "cooking," but your palate won't be able to tell the difference. Both the presentation and flavors are perfection. Bottom Line: Make a point to go there if you're going to be in Madrid. Book ahead.

title_review: The most amazing joyful meal.  Truly genius. Worth every euro!
review_preview: You are not given a menu for the meal until after it was over and only the Menu Degustacion was served.  That practice is perfect for after 20 "tastes" you realize that part of the experience is the surprise to both your eyes, your tastebuds...
review_full: You are not given a menu for the meal until after it was over and only the Menu Degustacion was served. That practice is perfect for after 20 "tastes" you realize that part of the experience is the surprise to both your eyes, your tastebuds and your sense of touch. Your senses of smell and hearing don't get left out either for the fizz of the foaming machines and the aroma of what looks like pot roast, but isn't. Our meal started with a gin fizz that was frozen on the bottom and was topped with a warm foam on top so that you experienced the cold through the warm. The gin fizz moustache made you laugh and then you were on to snacks of the sweetest paper thin dried carrot rolled into a cigar shape and garnished with a tiny dollop of licorice sauce, a one bite savory "pizza", a walnut and truffle sponge that truly looked and felt like a sponge, and a tiny "ice cream sandwich" which was cold and had the smooth texture of ice cream but was savory parmesan cheese. After 8 of these little snacks eaten with fingers only, you are smiling, having fun, and feeling like a child, but a child with very sophisticated tastes.  Silverware is brought and then what I call the trompe l'oeil courses are served. The peach which is really frozen essence of tomato only 1/4 inch thick surrounds warm mozarella foam on a bed of basil and balsamic sauces and the poached egg that isn't an egg at all. The John Dory fish was served with five different preparations of lemon sauce each more delicate and flavorful than the one you just tasted. I hardly wanted to put them on the fish which was delicious by itself, but the combination was divine. I loved this meal. You get the idea. It is affliated with the genius, Ferran Adria of El Bulli, and if you can't go there, La Terraza is a great second.

We can complain as much as we like and jacket requirements will never be changed simply because they have enough events, dinners and celebrations organized by them self they do not value opinion of guests who come here for single visit. So we must endure for the food experience, 3.5 hrs later, having one course in the kitchen, after 21 course in total I can say bring that jacket with you. What you will experience is complete synergy in between kitchen with food prepared, and staff served food on your table. Dishes perfectly prepared, correct temperature when served, when dish explained you receive guidance how to eat it because meals looks deceptive and often you end up tasting unexpected. Wine list is powerful, it is actually thick as a book. Must reserve your table for this experience

title_review: Excellent service for poorly cooked food
review_preview: Most Michelin stars awarded outside of France, and including some 3 stars within the tourist areas in Paris, are awarded with poor judgement. It is true again with this restaurant. Their classical French dishes were tasteless, and the sauces flat. The cuts of meat were...
review_full: Most Michelin stars awarded outside of France, and including some 3 stars within the tourist areas in Paris, are awarded with poor judgement. It is true again with this restaurant. Their classical French dishes were tasteless, and the sauces flat. The cuts of meat were of low quality. Even the 'molecular cuisine, the silly new cooking trend, or more correctly termed, 'food dunked in liquid nitrogen' dunked liquid, was not comparable to that at Bel Canto in Lisbon. However, the service was impeccable and the setting was truly Michelin 2-stars.

review_preview: Had lunch with wife on July 10th.  Chef is a disciple of Ferran Adrià of El Bulli (which is difficult to reach, impossible to get a reservation, and 2x the price). We did the menu degustation, which consisted of 16 courses and 24 tastes, beginning...
review_full: Had lunch with wife on July 10th. Chef is a disciple of Ferran Adrià of El Bulli (which is difficult to reach, impossible to get a reservation, and 2x the price). We did the menu degustation, which consisted of 16 courses and 24 tastes, beginning with a Mojito with dry ice, and continuing with a multitude of wonderful tastes including pesto gnocchis with baby cuttlefish, carbonara egg nest and rabbit with glazed onions and wild mushrooms. The deserts were magnificent my favorite being a coulant- nitro con hazelnut (hazelnut made with dry ice). Magnificent service. I have eaten at Jean-Georges, Gordon Ramsay, Robuchon and countless other haute cuisine restaurants, and I would have to rank La Terrazza top among them, given the creativity of the menu and amicality of the service

I loved the gazpacho with the shrimp, the different olive oils processed in a fancy way, the fish and meat and the dessert! I felt totally like a queen and the lunch was just perfect even no one else was at the restaurant new benchmark is set! Congratulations to the chef!!!

title_review: Maybe the best meal anywhere ever
review_preview: Don't listen to those who claim it is overestimated, too fussy or the like. This is the second time my wife and I have been here. The first time was 3 years ago. We were blown away then and blown away now. The setting on...
review_full: Don't listen to those who claim it is overestimated, too fussy or the like. This is the second time my wife and I have been here. The first time was 3 years ago. We were blown away then and blown away now. The setting on the roof is divine. The food is innovative and surprising. Even though there is a set menu (either 12 or 16 courses), they will cater to any dietary restrictions. My wife is close to vegan and I am a carnivore. No worries. 2 different meals both sublime. They also have an extensive and reasonably priced wine list with multiple selections between $40-100, which for a restaurant of this caliber is both unusual and welcome. It may be expensive but including a nice bottle of Rioja about the same price as 2 tickets to a popular Broadway show. The meal lasts about as long and I walked away much more satisfied from this than Hello Dolly!

review_preview: The atmosphere is beautiful but the food is definitely not worth the money at all. The chef is trying too hard to be innovative. The food falls apart, doesn't stay together, literally, and really is not good. The restaurant should keep it simple and work...
review_full: The atmosphere is beautiful but the food is definitely not worth the money at all. The chef is trying too hard to be innovative. The food falls apart, doesn't stay together, literally, and really is not good. The restaurant should keep it simple and work off the wonderful fruits and vegetables and meat of Spain. Cooking doesn't need this much work. We paid a fifth of the price the previous evening and had food and wine that catered to our tastes and not the whims of the kitchen. Please avoid. There are much better, more authentic experiences and not for 400 euros for just two people. Avoid the culinary gimmicks of this restaurant.

review_full: One reason for our bringing friends to Madrid was so that we could visit The Casino restaurant again. We were not disappointed! The service was friendly and discrete; the quality and range of their unique dishes was remarkable: no other restaurant has an amuse bouch of olive oil 4 ways-1 frozen, 2 melt-in- the mouth olive pastilles with a carpaccio of olive. The raviolis made with prawn and marinated fish, roasted hake and a creme caramel with 5 different fruits were stand out dishes- all from the tasting menu The dining room is in a beautiful setting too. Booking essential-do not miss it on a trip to Madrid

review_preview: This place did not disappoint. They started with a visit to a food lab where we had a really good selection of snacks accompanied by really good explanations. Then we had the tasting menu which were innovative and tasted really good. The portions were small...
review_full: This place did not disappoint. They started with a visit to a food lab where we had a really good selection of snacks accompanied by really good explanations.  Then we had the tasting menu which were innovative and tasted really good. The portions were small but we were really full (in a good way) at the end. Even the bread selection were good. The service was amazing too.  We opted for the wine tasting menu, which came with 6 wines from white, red to dessert. They were mostly good and well paired and the sommelier was very attentive. However I would have preferred more explanation about the wines to get to know these Spanish wines from different regions.  It is worth the visit!

review_preview: Someone had recommended this restaurant to us and it did not disappoint. We went for the lunch terrazza tasting menu, which was the perfect amount of food. If we had gone for the larger tasting menu, I'm not sure if we would have been able...
review_full: Someone had recommended this restaurant to us and it did not disappoint. We went for the lunch terrazza tasting menu, which was the perfect amount of food. If we had gone for the larger tasting menu, I'm not sure if we would have been able to finish everything. The appetizers were highlights for me, but all the food had such a wonderful blend of flavors. The service was also great and the wine selection was incredibly extensive. I'd recommend this place to anyone looking for a nice fun meal out.

There is a catwalk of staff bringing down the next showstopper, each dish a masterpiece. A must while in Madrid. Will most certainly return.

review_preview: I write seldom critics and when only for the best Restaurants for me in the world.I have visited so many from the San Pellegrino List and from Guide Michelin that I can´t count it.Before I have to say I was this week also...
review_full: I write seldom critics and when only for the best Restaurants for me in the world. I have visited so many from the San Pellegrino List and from Guide Michelin that I can´t count it. Before I have to say I was this week also at Ramon Freixa and Diverxo. ( I have also been in El Club allard last year which is on the range like Freixa)  I have lost faith in all lists after I visited Diverxo whicht I think is for me absolutely overrated and not worth the Money. Ramon Freixa was much better but also to arbitray. Luck for me I got a table in La Terrazza and I got back my faith. From the first to the last dish it was a pure pleasure which I had the last time at Berasategui in San Sebastian.  I took the Menü Degustation. The Starters where fantastic and for me the highlight was the White chocolate and the foie domino.  After the starters I had a perfect carbonara pizze with truffe- and olive oil masked as bonbons. Then I was invited to see the kitchen where I got a fantastic Chilli crab buns - thanks to the nice guys in the kitchen. Later I have had wonderful Scampi Ravioli, with tuna foie- great. Also the lobster was perfect served with Pancetta. The last main course the rabbit was my Highlight. I loved the taste of cocoa. Sweet provocation with strawberry and cream followed by chocolate and when you are full the waiter came with a cart full of sweeties. At the end you´re satisfied and lucky. For me a memorable dining night and under my Top 10 in the world.  Only one thing I have to criticize not for me but it´s possible that it disturb guests. I got a vew very good and delicious wines. The presentation is very simple you get the wine that´s it. No explanation in Detail about the Grape usw. For me it´s very OK I don´t like to hear about this things I only wan´t to drink the wine and it´s good or not.  Eventually next time speak with the guest if they want´t a explanation or not. All in all one ot the best meals in the last years. I come back to Madrid and of course to La Terraza.

review_preview: We made a reservation here for our anniversary dinner prior to visiting Madrid. I cannot justly describe this experience - from the ambience on the terrace (yes at the end of September), light live music playing, the attentive waiters, the surrounding views of nighttime Madrid...
review_full: We made a reservation here for our anniversary dinner prior to visiting Madrid. I cannot justly describe this experience - from the ambience on the terrace (yes at the end of September), light live music playing, the attentive waiters, the surrounding views of nighttime Madrid and the star of the show the cuisine. The courses were inventive (olive oils cleverly disguised as olives), the tea with the dim sum and the rabbit oh my it all was cooked to perfection and tantalized the tastebuds. The meal is pricey but it’s worth it in my humble opinion. We have eaten in various Michelin starred restaurants and La Terrazo del Casino de Madrid is firmly among our favorites. We shall definitely return when we are next in Madrid.

review_preview: Arrived at the Casino which appears to be more of a members club, a few minutes before 9.00pm and were asked to wait which seemed strange. It soon became clear that this is because you are first taken to Chef Roncero’s “workshop” for some “snacks”,...
review_full: Arrived at the Casino which appears to be more of a members club, a few minutes before 9.00pm and were asked to wait which seemed strange. It soon became clear that this is because you are first taken to Chef Roncero’s “workshop” for some “snacks”, as they were called. They were fantastic....what looked like black and green olives (they weren’t) were filled with the most amazing olive oil, more olive oil frozen in nitrogen before an incredibly light creation involving prawns. From here onto the restaurant which is small and bright. Impeccable service from a smartly dressed team which included a sommelier who really understood what we wanted and recommended a fantastic white from Rioja.  The tasting menu was well balanced and thoroughly enjoyable although a couple of dishes missed the mark for us, especially the Rooster which really was an acquired taste. The desserts were spot on and if you don’t mind a bit of theatrics, which we don’t, you’ll have an enjoyable evening.

title_review: Artistic Creative Dining at it's Best
review_preview: We made our reservation months in advance to dine at chef Guerrero's restaurant.  The atmosphere was casual, yet alive.  Our table was next to the kitchen and it was great to watch the preparation of all the courses.  The first course is an interactive one...
review_full: We made our reservation months in advance to dine at chef Guerrero's restaurant. The atmosphere was casual, yet alive. Our table was next to the kitchen and it was great to watch the preparation of all the courses. The first course is an interactive one anyway, but seeing all in action was very impressive. We choose the 14 course meal and was surprised and educated with each course. We have been traveling in Portugal and Spain for over one week and this experience was definitely our best dining experience. Don't dine here if you are looking for a traditional meal, if you are looking for a culinary artistic delicious experience , this place should not be missed. Dishes were prepared with local ingredients from all over the world and explained in great detail by the extremely knowledgeable staff, which was necessary to learn how one should eat some of the dishes. One of the deserts was the best I have ever had! I won't ruin the surprise. Price was very reasonable for a Michelin restaurant. Great job to all!

review_preview: We were delighted that we were able to make a booking for lunch six weeks before our visit.  We had telephone calls and emails confirming our visit.  We had an excellent flight of 17 courses with wine pairing.  Service was excellent, even when the restaurant...
review_full: We were delighted that we were able to make a booking for lunch six weeks before our visit. We had telephone calls and emails confirming our visit. We had an excellent flight of 17 courses with wine pairing. Service was excellent, even when the restaurant (kitchen and wait staff) was at capacity. The start of the experience is in the bar, then progresses to the kitchen area where another course is prepared in front of you. We were sitting near the open kitchen and it was a delight to watch the calm methodical workings of the chefs: concentration seemed more intense when the full restaurant was its busiest but there was no noise (talking, pans, etc.). The wait staff were excellent fully explaining each dish, how to eat the dish (actually very helpful!) and the wine selected to enhance at least one aspect of the dish. We were surprised how wonderful we felt at the end of the 17 courses, we had eaten an 'elegant sufficiency' but did not feel overly full. A great experience, which we highly recommend.

review_preview: This is visit four, and review three. In fact, we have to declare a - vague - personal connection with Dstage. We used to congratulate - and, I fear, slightly terrify - the chef patron on his frequent collecting of Michelin stars when we bumped...
review_full: This is visit four, and review three. In fact, we have to declare a - vague - personal connection with Dstage. We used to congratulate - and, I fear, slightly terrify - the chef patron on his frequent collecting of Michelin stars when we bumped into him in the lift in our building. If you find yourself with a spare €100, and you decide you deserve to spend it on yourself, do it here. This is, surely, as good as any restaurant in the world. If there are better, what can they be like? Our problem is how to review a restaurant without ruining it for you. You eat in three different places. An aperitif, usually seafood based, at the bar. Followed by another, prepared and explained on the spot by one of the dozen or so chefs at the pass in front of the (open) kitchen. You're lead through this - every dish, in detail - in the language of your choice, English or Spanish. The decor and atmosphere are simple and look smart. Exposed brick. Aluminium aircon ducting, Spotlights. Modern wooden furniture. Think, and this is a positive, brand new Pizza Express in a refurbished Victorian brewery furnished by Habitat. Tables are very large. Two of you will be seated at a place that could seat six at a push. The sense of space in a restaurant in this city is very refreshing. The fact is you shouldn't look at the photos or even read the reviews. You should go for the whole experience which has to include the surprise - the amazement - which some dishes provoke. But we're going to spoil two for you because you should ask for them on your tasting menu. Raviolis. It's the boss's signature dish. Three ravioli. A consomme. And three orange beans. And some tiny pieces of something like microscopic spring onion. And it's a work of genius. It's fabada. Condensed into three or so mouthfuls. It's the heaviest dish in the world turned into something light and still full of all the intense flavour it should have. You'll find yourself ekeing out that consomme. And those beans. They ain't beans. That's the sauce. Trapped in a bean! Maiz. There's a sort-of popcorn covered baked alaska, surrounded by candy floss. Sitting on the base of the plate, and we could write an article on the beauty of the serving dishes, is a sauce/jam/gunge of sweet stuff that ends with a hint of chilli. Rub your candy floss in it. Grab it in both hands and stuff lumps of the thing in your mouth. Then try to think of some adjectives with a silly grin on your face. Finally, tidy up with the hot towel that's magically appeared. Service is spookily, eye-openingly efficient. New plates and cutlery appear like magic. Wine and water are served silently and for once it's not to make you get through it quicker, it just keeps your table smart and tidy. We'd recommend one near the kitchen to see the magic being created in a remarkable sea of tranquility. And that's it. You want more? Every food website going will go into exhaustive detail of every dish with photos plastered all over. Don't bother. Go and have your surprises like your dinner. Expect the unexpected.

title_review: One of the best restaurants I've visited
review_preview: Everything about Dstage was faultless. The restaurant itself was intentionally understated with a relaxed welcoming atmosphere. The kitchen is within the dining area meaning that diners can watch the kitchen at work and allows interaction between diners and chefs. The dishes were all beautiful in...
review_full: Everything about Dstage was faultless. The restaurant itself was intentionally understated with a relaxed welcoming atmosphere. The kitchen is within the dining area meaning that diners can watch the kitchen at work and allows interaction between diners and chefs. The dishes were all beautiful in terms of taste and presentation, it was clear that a lot of time and thought had gone into creating every course. In terms of the quality of the food and the overall experience I found this to be incredibly good value for money and as is typical in Spain we didn't find ourselves being overcharged for extras, for example a glass of wine was €5. The waiting staff were also excellent, proving explanations if the food and drinks in English and provided an unrushed pace of service. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.

title_review: "Great but It was not too surprising"
review_preview: I had great expectations for this pricey place considering all reviews and the fact it is in Madrid: a food paradise. Anyway, it is a worthy experience. At some point, dishes based on ingredient combinations producing unexpected flavor was kind of repetitive. Overall, it is...
review_full: I had great expectations for this pricey place considering all reviews and the fact it is in Madrid: a food paradise. Anyway, it is a worthy experience. At some point, dishes based on ingredient combinations producing unexpected flavor was kind of repetitive. Overall, it is must-go visit if you like restaurants based on several-step dinners. Tip: It better to avoid the wine pairing and select the wine bottle by yourself.

Highlight dishes were: blue mesa (corn) w fermented yucca, pumpkin seeds w a special coconut water drink, salmon ears w kohlrabi, corn w cotton candy dessert. Pushed the 'creative' envelope of molecular 'just far enough' but not off the rails like some 2 star places I've been. Highly recommend.

review_full: 2 daughters (food conneseurs), son-in-law, & me to lunch on the way to Marrakech via NYC.  Upon arrival, greeted taken to cocktail table, ordered aperitifs, then 1st course arrived: Roman style squid in sort of mist. Excellent dish, probably the best of all. After completing this,mtaken to the bar counter opp the kitchen where we viewed the next course being developed: king prawn cebiche. This was the 2nd best flavored dish, or #1 by some. From Australia, king prawn seemed a bit small, ours are much larger, but we're in Spain! Then taken to the table where the next 10 courses were served:  Michigan, sweet mole, corn & tuba Tomato Garum Ladosa Red pepper rose, Crayfish, garlic & kombu Roasted fish skin & tuna toffe + other ones. In conclusion this was a superb experience. Many different items on each dish, some miniscule hard to view. No argument place is an epicurean experience & not to be missed while in Madrid. Atmosphere is really laid back but service is 1st class. The only critique from all if us the majority of the dishes lacked flavour except the 1st two. Nothing really hit you in your palate where you would say: H Sh! But it takes nothing away from our 4+ star rating!

review_preview: The restaurant’s name is not on the outside of the building, neither is the number 8, Calle de Regueros. When you do find the entrance a warm welcome awaits once you find D Stage. Your coat is taken and you’re directed to a seating area...
review_full: The restaurant’s name is not on the outside of the building, neither is the number 8, Calle de Regueros. When you do find the entrance a warm welcome awaits once you find D Stage. Your coat is taken and you’re directed to a seating area by the bar. A staff member arrives to take a drink order and explain the number of courses, 12, 14, 16 and ask after any food allergies. We opted for the middle number as we thought this would give us a good exploration of DSTAgE’s talents. I can tell you what we had on the day which may or not be available any other day. Despite my furious taking of notes of each course description given by the well briefed staff who brought each course to the table I needn’t have bothered. At the end of the meal we were given a nicely printed card with all the courses along with the wines.  While enjoying our drink in the bar we were presented with a smoking wooden tray covered in fresh briny seaweed and barnacle shells. Nestled in the middle was a pair of Roman style squid - soft pillows of squid that delighted when eaten   We were then escorted to the kitchen were our next course of King Prawn cebiche was prepared for us on a large block of rock salt then placed on a small square of banana leaf for us to eat. The head of the King Prawn provided the sauce for the dish. Then to our table.  A spare wooden table with only a napkin and water glass. The next few courses followed one after the other: A Mochi with a centre of sweet mote and tuba (fermented coconut water) accompanied by a glass of Ariyanas Dulce 2012 from Malaga. Then a Tomato with garum, with seaweed, anchovies, and black olives. Roasted avocado with peanut sauce and Vietnamese negus with a glass of Seda liquida Grand Cru Sake from Girona. An astonishing combination that shouldn’t work but went perfectly together. The next course was a Basque Roasted Red Pepper with red pepper rose topped with bread squares with Bat Gara Uno 2014 DO Txakoli di Alava. Stupidly good!! On to the Cod fish skin with nori sauce and confit of Tuna Eye. Each course brings with it another ingredient one would never guess. This one tasted heavily of the sea owing to the confit process. The wine was a Priorat from Scala Dei Pis dels Angels, 2017. Next was a presentation dish from the kitchen brought to the table and deconstructed. It was a large banana shallot roasted in a shell of coffee powder. The shell was cracked ad the soft succulent shallot reveals then sliced on to a plate with mushrooms and a coffee sauce. These ingredients blended together all the flavours of umami, especially when accompany by a refreshing glass of Ximenez Spinola Exceptional Harvest 2016 from Jerez. Wonderful.  On to the fish course. A chunky piece of brined cod topped with pieces of thin and crispy chicken skin. With this a glass of Sartenes o Canciones 2015 DO Ribera Sacra went perfectly. Now for the meat course, a 30 hour braised shoulder of lamb melted on to the plate topped with Kombu, cogollo and piparra, along with the Xentia 2015 Extramadura.  For fun there was a melon and fermented beet root presented on a cub of ice, eaten with the fingers in one bite. Dessert was a feuillette of fermented purple carrot with a layer of vanilla toffee. What’s listed on our menu as Corn was nothing of the sort. It was a cloud of candy floss sprinkled with corn with a quenelle of popcorn ice cream in the centre on a base of mango sauce. Eaten with the hands, impossible to eat with a fork, it brought back all the memories of a summer fun fair when you left with sticky fingers and face. Our meal at DSTAgE ended with warm towels so you cold wipe off the sticky delicious candy floss if you hadn’t already licked your fingers clean.  To finish off there was a petit four of a meringue shaped and coloured like a head of garlic. And it tasted of garlic as well. It was definitely a lunch to remember.

title_review: Delicious innovative food great ambiance and service
review_preview: I attach a photo of the 14 course tasting menu (you can have 17!) with wine parings of 8 wines. The decor is post modern like the inside of a converted warehouse the kitchen and the numerous chefs is in full view of the diners...
review_full: I attach a photo of the 14 course tasting menu (you can have 17!) with wine parings of 8 wines. The decor is post modern like the inside of a converted warehouse the kitchen and the numerous chefs is in full view of the diners but for all that it is cozy and there is a really friendly atmosphere not at all 'stuck up' or formal. The first course is served at the bar before moving to the kitchen for the second course and then to your table. All the food was interesting innovative and delicious, the wines were well paired but just a warning each glass of wine for the paring was very generous probably 125ml so after 8 glasses I was feeling the effects, if you aren't a big drinker be warned (unlike most restaurants where the paring glasses are small even mean). Whilst not cheap this was good value the meal that was closest to this in style I have had was at Funky Gourmet in Athens and that was 50% more expensive. Couple of points to note toilet facilities downstairs are fantastic worth a visit even if you don't need them! and typical Spanish they don't open until 9pm we arrived at 8.45pm for a 9pm booking and had to leave and come back. Thoroughly recommend DStage for an interesting and enjoyable evening

review_preview: We had really looked forward to this meal and it was certainly not our first Michelin star restaurant. The service was fine and the food was ok - but for this price we expect to be “blown away” and we simply were not. Yes it...
review_full: We had really looked forward to this meal and it was certainly not our first Michelin star restaurant.  The service was fine and the food was ok - but for this price we expect to be “blown away” and we simply were not.  Yes it is clever cooking and there were some lovely flavors but there was not enough texture in the food. Too much purée and foam in all 14 courses left us frustrated and, in the end, just waiting for it to be over.  We have now been in Spain for over two weeks and have had some fantastic meals for a quarter of the price.  There is no way we would recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: In the famous and cult Godfrey Reggio movie, images and sounds chase each other in a vortex of emotions and sensations that leave the audience open-jawed and glued to the screen. Not a single word is spoken, as to underline the limitations of language or...
review_full: In the famous and cult Godfrey Reggio movie, images and sounds chase each other in a vortex of emotions and sensations that leave the audience open-jawed and glued to the screen. Not a single word is spoken, as to underline the limitations of language or speech when describing that great show that life is. This is pretty much how I felt when going through the DSTAGE experience. The eyes and the mouth were on a roller-coaster of feelings, one fooling the other, leaving to the brain and the heart the strenuous duty of deciphering what was going on in front of them.  A tumultuous feast of 'trampantojos' - where everything tastes different from the way it looks - expects you from the moment you sit down at the table. You will still be debating with your partners what the last thing you ate was, trying to get a hint from the name given to the concoction or the kind explanation offered by the waiter, when the next delicious surprise will have landed in front of you. Adventurous, daring, elaborate, whether you will like everything that you will taste is irrelevant. I certainly did. What matters is what happens subconsciously, when an unexpected taste transports you elsewhere for a fraction of a moment. It's the playfulness of the unknown, the child-like curiosity that tickles our being when we crack open an Easter egg. This is no ordinary restaurant, it's a an amusement park for your taste buds. If you think they deserve an extraordinary experience you ought to take them there now.

review_preview: Either you hate it or you love it. Deigo dares to experiment and brings many flavors to challenge your senesce - curry, chili. The place, unlike where Diego came from. is informal and one got the chance to mix with the staffs I(chefs too). One...
review_full: Either you hate it or you love it. Deigo dares to experiment and brings many flavors to challenge your senesce - curry, chili. The place, unlike where Diego came from. is informal and one got the chance to mix with the staffs I(chefs too). One can choose the short or long menu (go for the long) and if you do not like certain foods or hate to repeat, he will try his best to change. We went there twice in one week and were totally impressed. Many of the top restaurants focused on plating, presentation and molecular manipulation or exotic sourcing. Diego brought dining back to the basic - smell, taste and freshness! The place is hard to find with no name. It is across from the equally good local Italian restaurant - Trattoria Pulcinella

title_review: A great experience; a mixed meal
review_preview: DSTAGE is a great experience. We went for an anniversary celebration, and had a memorable meal-- including a stop at the kitchen for an appetizer, and a visit from the chef. Some of the dishes were wonderful and inventive. Others were just inventive, and the...
review_full: DSTAGE is a great experience. We went for an anniversary celebration, and had a memorable meal-- including a stop at the kitchen for an appetizer, and a visit from the chef. Some of the dishes were wonderful and inventive. Others were just inventive, and the full menu didn't come together as well as it could-- so, 4 stars rather than 5. I would recommend it highly as a one-time experience, but I don't think I'd make a repeat visit.

title_review: The best haute cuisine restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: It is difficult to describe Dstage, apart from to say that it is one of the best haute cuisine restaurants I have ever been to.    It was my second visit but I enjoyed it as much as the first.  This modern storytelling creative food restaurant...
review_full: It is difficult to describe Dstage, apart from to say that it is one of the best haute cuisine restaurants I have ever been to. It was my second visit but I enjoyed it as much as the first. This modern storytelling creative food restaurant with a casual atmosphere is the success story of Diego Guerrero who came from the 2 michelin star restaurant Club Allard. Dstage has only been in existence for 11 months yet already has its first star. If you want to book a table you need to do so 4 months in advance. The story of Dstage has reached many parts of the world through foodie tourists who have told its tale and posted photos of the wonderful culinary creations; each one a piece of art. It even reached The New York Times and I am sure that this article has something to do with its ever increasing popularity. I think in the haute cuisine category, it is surely Madrid’s number one. I look forward to seeing it next year in the top 10 or so of The Restaurant. It certainly deserves to be there. I loved the way the evening went. First you have a "tapa" with a drink at the bar, then you are taken to the bar of the kitchen and a chef makes your next course there and then in front of you. Afterwards you are taken to your table. Each course after that is served by a waiter or waitress who sometimes prepares the courses for you. That way you get to see how things are made. It's amazing.  The only thing that needs improving at Dstage is the spoken English of its employees. They all speak it or more probably have learned off by heart how to describe the dishes. The problem is that is nearly impossible to understand what they are saying as their pronunciation is so bad. I am seriously thinking of offering them private lessons in English pronunciation. Maybe I will get a free meal in exchange. Well that would be a good barter wouldn’t it?

Those few in our group of 16 who did not immediately put it as their top gourmet experience ever, still all had it on their top three list. They were the comparing DSTAgE to Noma (Copenhagen), L'abielle (Paris) and a small handful of top Michelin *** resturants. Thank you to Chef Diego Guerrero and his team at DSTAgE, on Thursday 4. september 2014, for giving us the best possible start to our long weekend in wonderful Madrid.

We were lucky to have had time to speak with the Chef at the service counter and again at the end of the experience.  Highly recommended.  I will post pictures later, but didn't want to delay my review any further.

review_preview: Me and my wife went to this restaurant cause we wanted to try something that was truly different. We are both foodies from the USA and we both work at restaurants. I has hesitant because i knew it was gonna be very expensive and i...
review_full: Me and my wife went to this restaurant cause we wanted to try something that was truly different. We are both foodies from the USA and we both work at restaurants. I has hesitant because i knew it was gonna be very expensive and i wasn't sure if it was gonna be strange for the sake of being strange. We got the tasting menu for 130E each. It is about 17 courses and i counted that i tried 23 different items (as some of the snacks had more than one item). The snacks portion of the tasting was the most unusal items. They very great and alot of fun. It got more traditional as the night went on. When we got to dessert, they made ice cream table side which was fun (even for me I am a pastry chef).  We made a long night of it, we took a break after the entrees to sit outside for about 15 minutes. They have a great patio outside that for some reason they don't use for dinner. People go out there for a smoke. We don't smoke but went out there to take pictures and get some fresh air. WE arrived at 8:30 and had drinks in the bar and we left at 1am. It was a night we will not forget. I have been lucky to eat at a few 3 star Michilin (Daniel NY, Le Bernadin NY, J. Robuchon,Toyko. This 2 star was my favorite of the all. It didn't come cheap 391 Euro for the 2 of us but it is a night we will never forget! That makes it worth every penny

title_review: Worth the money and Michelin 2 star quality
review_preview: We ordered the full tasting menu which was priced around EUR120 per person. As a starter, the finger food appetisers were very delicately interesting and paired well with different types of olive oil. Yes there's a lot of olive oil but it is really a...
review_full: We ordered the full tasting menu which was priced around EUR120 per person. As a starter, the finger food appetisers were very delicately interesting and paired well with different types of olive oil. Yes there's a lot of olive oil but it is really a tea spoonful only each dish, it wont make you full all of a sudden. Eg packed in rice paper, or in an infused ball - the El bulli way. After that, we had the mains which were equally creative eg scampi in seafood stock, Iberico pork which is diced and fried, etc. the vegetable garden and the boiled egg is truly sensational - which is beyond words. Won't go into detail to ruin your experience. Dessert is good and the Citrus ice cream is paired well with small bites of orange and lemon skin, custard, sesame, marshmallow and a few other flavours. The food ingredient may not be posh or expensive, but the chef has used many ways to add different flavours to make it memorable. You will be guessing and guessing what you are eating.  Service is decent but it would be better if they went into detail of the food on the table, which is standard Michelin 3 star.  Last but not least, the cockscomb was a bit too oily, not to my liking.

title_review: Run by a disciple of the great chef Ferran Adria of the late 'El Bulli"
review_preview: You shouldn't go there just to eat and, whatever you do, have one of the tasting menus. Even after 13 courses you will still be interested. Each course is a small but extraordinary experience and even the most oddball thing, like the 'vegetable garden' is...
review_full: You shouldn't go there just to eat and, whatever you do, have one of the tasting menus. Even after 13 courses you will still be interested. Each course is a small but extraordinary experience and even the most oddball thing, like the 'vegetable garden' is delightful. OK, not every course is an entirely new, wonderful, eyepopping experience, as they were at 'El Bulli' but Adria was a genius. The chefs at La Terraza are merely seriously good. The difference between this and the usual (rather boring) Michelin star experience is that every course is imaginative and novel. You won't be eating stuff you have eaten a hundred times but which is very well cooked, presented and expensive. Here, every new course is original and brilliantly done. It beats the 'Fat Duck' hands down and there is no childish nonsense about wearing headphones for certain dishes or being forced to have the 'Mad Hatter's Tea Party.' These people are serious about food, the Spanish are serious about food and they do not need gimmicks to make them believe that the food is innovative. Oh, and leave the wines to them. They know their list and how to match things.

title_review: Great food in a great location
review_preview: We had a business dinner at La Terraza in a larger group (around 30 people), starting with a reception in the entrance area and a seated dinner in a spectacular room on the first floor. I really loved the plush location with its almost baroque...
review_full: We had a business dinner at La Terraza in a larger group (around 30 people), starting with a reception in the entrance area and a seated dinner in a spectacular room on the first floor. I really loved the plush location with its almost baroque decor. The food is quite experimental (I am not sure if it is pure-play "molecular" cuisine) and very tasty. Just the service was quite unpersonal, maybe this had to do with the fact that we were a large group and almost all not Spanish-speaking. I would definitely test the location for a private dinner next time I'm in Madrid.

title_review: One of the Best Dinners We've Had Anywhere
review_preview: This 2-star Michelin restaurant in the heart of Madrid certainly lived up to its reputation.  We had a special birthday dinner there for 2 and loved it.  We had the menu degustacion that was incredible:  a symphony of tastes, textures and witty presentation.  It would...
review_full: This 2-star Michelin restaurant in the heart of Madrid certainly lived up to its reputation. We had a special birthday dinner there for 2 and loved it. We had the menu degustacion that was incredible: a symphony of tastes, textures and witty presentation. It would take too long to describe the 8 "snacks" that they started with or the 9 "tapiplatos" that constituted the main part of the dinner or the 3 courses of dessert. One thing deserves mention: they prepared a fruit sorbet at the table for us using liquid nitrogen - swirling fog all over. It was quite impressive. The sommelier helped us pick an excellent Spanish Chardonnay that did not break the bank. Also, for the last tapiplato of venizon loin the sommelier insisted we have a glass of rioja. Later they offered us sherry and port with dessert. They never charged us for anything but the bottle of wine. A beautiful, elegant space, great service (decent English) and remarkable food.

title_review: Elegance to the nth degree! (and the food is great too)
review_preview: We ended our visit to Spain with a great meal at La Terrazza, an elegant restaurant located on the top floor of the "Casino de Madrid" (this is not an actual casino). We happen to dine on the same night as the Casino was hosting...
review_full: We ended our visit to Spain with a great meal at La Terrazza, an elegant restaurant located on the top floor of the "Casino de Madrid" (this is not an actual casino). We happen to dine on the same night as the Casino was hosting a wedding reception -so the evening was made more glamourous by the sight of many men and women dressed in their best, celebrating a joyous occasion. You are transported to the restaurant in an old fashioned elevator with a folding brass gate and velvet settee. The restaurant is beautiful, with mirrors lining many of the walls. We opted for the smaller of the 2 tasting menus and selected wines with the help of the sommelier. As with other top tier restaurants in Spain, each course was a small work of art, beautifully presented. Every course was delicious, with some unexpected combinations of flavors. Dietary restrictions were accommodated without fuss or difficulty (every high end restaurant we booked actually asked us in advance about food allergies or restrictions). The wine list was expansive and fairly priced for a high end major city restaurant. Service was friendly and attentive. If you are able to dine in warm weather, ask if you can sit outside on the terrace. Dinner which included 2 bottles of wine and several glasses of dessert wine was about $190 per person. Would happily dine here again

Only one table chose the traditional picking their own dishes.  The start was great with a really unique mojito. Starters were nice and interesting but main courses were somehow disappointing.  The soup was unbeatable! The rest didn't have it because they had the cheaper menu. When we had a main course of a fish (was delicious) the rest of the tables got right after that a risotto, while we got an extra of two more deserts (I asked a sugar free meal- got everything with sugar except for the one dish that actually justifies sugar, while I DID mentioned by mail that I would like to try all dishes as the chef would desire in order to fully enjoy the experience)- I had a fruit salad (which BTW is full of sugar like a peace of pie for that matter..) while my partner had an amazing desert.  Rest of the tables mentioned they are full and happy so we couldn't avoid thinking that the risotto is probably a satisfying dish (looked great too, but we didn't get it because we paid more...) Left the place hungry and poor...  Some of the dishes were great but we would enjoy more the lass dishes option eventually. Oh! And they don't have a cocktail menu!!! W?!

review_preview: Sweetie and I were very pleased with our overall experience. We chose the Grand Menu, and were wowed by the molecular approach taken. The wine pairings were also excellent, and service was excellent on all aspects. The only hiccup in the evening is the order...
review_full: Sweetie and I were very pleased with our overall experience. We chose the Grand Menu, and were wowed by the molecular approach taken. The wine pairings were also excellent, and service was excellent on all aspects. The only hiccup in the evening is the order of two dishes, the first meat dish and the last fish dish, which should be fish first and meat after, in order for the wine to work properly. This is not the case, however, so ask for a red wine when you get the first meat dish and hang on to your white wine glasses, as they will bring fish after. This decision is from the back of the house, not the front. Notwithstanding this hiccup, sweetie and I had a lot of fun, and we will go back the next time we are in Madrid.

review_preview: When you walk into the Casino, you'll notice it's really more a private club; but you're in the right place.  Shortly after you enter, there's a desk where someone can assist you with the elevator you'll need to take to reach the upper floor location...
review_full: When you walk into the Casino, you'll notice it's really more a private club; but you're in the right place. Shortly after you enter, there's a desk where someone can assist you with the elevator you'll need to take to reach the upper floor location of the restaurant. The entire place is white-themed and thus the ethereal description. The service is impeccable and you'll feel akin to royalty dining here. The atmosphere was a bit on the sterile side (I've never eaten in such an extremely "white" locale), but the food was very innovative and the abundant whiteness makes the food the focus. There are three different tasting menus that vary by price and number of courses. The olive oil packets were perhaps the least appealing of the courses but for the most part, we found all the other dishes quite intriguing (a la molecular to a point) and delicious. I've included pictures to illustrate our meal. This location is a great romantic destination for that special evening.

title_review: Worth a Million Stars and More!
review_preview: As each year goes by this restaurant continues to evolve and re-invent its cuisine. With its recent 2 Michelin star rating,  I don't doubt Diego and his team will achieve a 3rd star soon. This was our 3rd time back. We enjoyed it so much...
review_full: As each year goes by this restaurant continues to evolve and re-invent its cuisine. With its recent 2 Michelin star rating, I don't doubt Diego and his team will achieve a 3rd star soon. This was our 3rd time back. We enjoyed it so much this time around, we have another reservation next month! For those of you who haven't been there, the menu is not a la carte (as most Michelin restaurants). When you call and are seated, they ask for your preferences and other intolerances etc.. I always say - mala comida (bad food). They now have 3 "experiences" which you can choose from 12 (Dtaste) - 14 (Dstage) - 17 (Denjoy) petite dishes. 14 was a healthy size for dinner and would recommend 17 for generous lunch. With 2 bottles of wine and cocktails expect to spend 350+ Euro for 2 people easy. In the past, Diego created playful dishes like "Faux-sabi" and "Garlic Meringue Dessert" however he has changed his approach to focus on straight forward dishes. There wasn't a dish we didn't like, usually there is at least one dish you're not a fan of. One of my favorites was his interpretation of "Chicken and Waffles". Roasted Squab served with a brioche waffle in an aromatic sauce. My partner didn't quite understand my amusement being Spanish.  It does take several month's to get a reservation.They limit it to 4 months out and best to do it online. Be patient it is well worth the wait. There is no valet parking as it is on a pedestrian only street.  Apart from the food, what really sets Dstage aside from all the other competitors is the atmosphere and customer service. While it is a well heeled crowd, you didn't feel like you were being judged by both the restaurant and guests. Everyone was there for Diego and to enjoy the experience. Even better was the wait and kitchen staff, despite being at least 10 months from our last visit and the volume they serve, they remembered us and our preferences. Both Cristina and Zulima were amazing and kept it very lively. Everyone was smiling and happy but still efficient and professional. Other restaurants can learn from this especially a certain 3* restaurant who has flying pigs on their walls.  My only negative comment - they are not open Saturdays or Sundays. Which to be honest, they deserve those two days off! Buen Provecho

title_review: More than just dinner, this is theatre!
review_preview: I will remember this experience until the day I die. The combination of probably the best setting in Madrid, the professionalism of the staff and the culinary sensations make this a very memorable experience.The setting on the rooftop of the Casino de Madrid is...
review_full: I will remember this experience until the day I die. The combination of probably the best setting in Madrid, the professionalism of the staff and the culinary sensations make this a very memorable experience. The setting on the rooftop of the Casino de Madrid is an amazing location made even more impressive with the setting sun. The staff in their pristine white outfits worked together like a well oiled machine, paying attention to every minute detail. The interplay of flavour, texture, technique, and presentation made for a deliciously entertaining food adventure. At 525 euros for 4 people including wines it was worth every cent!

title_review: An unbelievable and Unforgetable Experience...Rooftop Madrid
review_preview: Molecular dining at its best!!! This really was one of those experiences, up there with Alain Ducasse in Paris! The setting on the rooftop is incredible. When we arrived (smartly dressed in coats and ties, I might add, even tho most others had just jackets,...
review_full: Molecular dining at its best!!! This really was one of those experiences, up there with Alain Ducasse in Paris! The setting on the rooftop is incredible. When we arrived (smartly dressed in coats and ties, I might add, even tho most others had just jackets, no ties) they told us our reservation had been canceled. I then showed them my confirmation from Amex AND an email I had written them just a few days earlier with all of the reservation info on it and to which I received a reply. I explained that since I had 2 forms of documentation showing my reservation, I was sure they must have documentation of my cancellation...uh...no...SO....they were very nice about fitting us in and everything ran great...They couldn't have been nicer about it and we knew they would fix it so no big deal...And glad it worked out...There was no menu, just plate after plate of molecular dishes of incredible flavor...Watermelon with frozen wasabe that tasted like tuna...Wine list was great and then..to be able to sit at your table and have Ice Wine, Port and a cigar!!!! BUT....save up....our bill was $500 per couple!!!!...and with that sticker shock, being on the rooftop may come in handy...But the experience will never be forgotten....

review_preview: From the moment you enter the absolutely stunning dining room the tone is set for an incredible dining experience. We were greeted with a very special pisco sour made with liquid nitrogen and served as a sort of sorbet in a frozen lime. We choose...
review_full: From the moment you enter the absolutely stunning dining room the tone is set for an incredible dining experience. We were greeted with a very special pisco sour made with liquid nitrogen and served as a sort of sorbet in a frozen lime. We choose to try the entire tasting menu (€135) which while admittedly expensive was more food than any human could reasonably be expected to consume. The cold almond soup served in carved stone bowls, the tiny olive oil pouches hanging from a "laundry line", and the literal garden brought to your table for you to create your own salad with tiny scissors were among my favorites. The flavors of the dishes are only enhanced by the sense of whimsy the chef provides.

title_review: Great start, but all that oil sent my friend to the toilet!
review_preview: The entrance is grand. And the old lift taking you up from another era. The restaurant has unfortunately been designed by a fan of Disneyland. Instead of mixing old with new, it's a Disney interpretation. Feels a bit fake. Anyway, dishes were lining up, one...
review_full: The entrance is grand. And the old lift taking you up from another era. The restaurant has unfortunately been designed by a fan of Disneyland. Instead of mixing old with new, it's a Disney interpretation. Feels a bit fake. Anyway, dishes were lining up, one more exciting than the next. Great creative suggestions. However olive oil on olive oil is not always a good idea.... And I guess creativity is here more important than a balanced diet.... Unfortunately, our evening ended therefore in the middle of the meal when my friend just made it to the toilet before throwing up! We got a slightly lower bill as compensation, but still a 300€+ bill for a ruined evening feels a bit high.... Hence, not sure it's a one or a five, so I give it a 3.

title_review: 2 Star Michelin Restaurant with some innovation but come for lunch
review_preview: Booking one month advance, I could only get dinner as lunch was full (probably as the tasting menu is only Euro 65 p.p. vs Euro 130 at dinner).  I ordered ala carte.  I thought the snacks/appetizers were innovative in presentation and tasty.  The main course...
review_full: Booking one month advance, I could only get dinner as lunch was full (probably as the tasting menu is only Euro 65 p.p. vs Euro 130 at dinner). I ordered ala carte. I thought the snacks/appetizers were innovative in presentation and tasty. The main course I selected which was steak which was apparently from a flower fed cow, was lean but tasteless. I dont know reason chef did not add a sauce to make it more interesting. The desert was average and I was disappointed it wasnt more innovative like the snacks.  The dining room designed by Spanish designer Jamie Hayon three years ago already looks a bit dated. Its formal dining so men need to wear jackets at all time but thankfully not ties! I would come back to this restaurant again but only at lunch and only to order the tasting menu so if you get a dish you do not like, it is only a small part of your meal.

title_review: It's more like a lab than a restaurant
review_preview: The restaurant has an excellent location, great setting and attentive service.  Spending ONE night there to impress your companions is worth the trip but if one is looking for a mouth-watering experience, I do not recommend this place.  Visited quite a number of similar innovative...
review_full: The restaurant has an excellent location, great setting and attentive service. Spending ONE night there to impress your companions is worth the trip but if one is looking for a mouth-watering experience, I do not recommend this place. Visited quite a number of similar innovative restuarants that serve molecular cuisine, most of them are highly rated michelin starred and for most of the time you don't get disappointed with the food. This time, nonetheless, I was surprised with the salty sauce of all the courses and also how they have not carefully considered the balancing of the ingredients, the sauce and the sides. I still believe it's a must-go for visitors of Spain just to appreciate a dinner at the OLD casino and experience a rather theatrical performance of the servers of the restuarant.
