review_preview: There is now and again a restaurant that you come across or stumble upon that surpasses all your hopes and expectations and for me DStage was the one for us in Madrid.I thought earlier in the week i had experienced excellence but in comparison...
review_full: There is now and again a restaurant that you come across or stumble upon that surpasses all your hopes and expectations and for me DStage was the one for us in Madrid. I thought earlier in the week i had experienced excellence but in comparison this is the one for us. We were afforded an excellent table where I could watch closely the machinations of the kitchen which throughout our visit, and under the constant watchful eye of Diego ran like clockwork without a flicker of panic or chaos. The restaurant is informal and unpretentious with enough of an air of class to raise it above the norm. The menu was creative and exciting and is a credit to the obvious abundant expertise and brilliant mind of the 'Master'. Our service throughout was excellent with an exceptional and varied (and somewhat off piste) wine pairing to the 14 course menu we chose and the important front of house team complements the excellence of the kitchen. Portion sizes were perfect and one of the best I've encountered in a long while and I was thankful to find that Diego does not conform to the general final meat dish generally served under lashings of a heavy duty, rich sauce which personally, kills even the best taster menu for me, and has the confidence in the quality of his ingredients to allow them to breathe and speak for themselves. Without giving too much of the surprise menu away and to avoid spoiling for others we much enjoyed the face to face preparation of the second snack taken at the kitchen counter. Every course was perfection in all aspects. However, I do like to share my least and most favourite main dishes which might be difficult in this instance but if forced to make a decision it would be least, the ravioli and most the bun. Desserts were to die (and kill for, although not literally) and obviously further creations from the exceptional mind of Diego, the execution of all 3 final flourishes were exemplary and my hat and applause goes to those who took part in order to deliver those triumphs to our table.  As a number one, DStage has taken the lead but I will, of course, keep searching to ascertain if it can be toppled in the future but for now this is where it is (for both of us).  This has to be the number one and am shocked that it only has the one star, come on Michelin get your finger out!! A true star under magnificent leadership I was proud to shake the hand of the genius. This is not just food presented on a plate but, indeed, works of art. We truly saved the best to last, excellent value for money and would I recommend it - what do you think!! Thank you all at DStage for an exceptional evening of the finest dining.

review_preview: I arrived in Madrid almost 9 months ago, and I’ve been in love with this city ever since. Each restaurant I’ve been to ended up being a delightful surprise, due to their welcoming and elegant setting as well as to their delectable savors, real delicacies...
review_full: I arrived in Madrid almost 9 months ago, and I’ve been in love with this city ever since. Each restaurant I’ve been to ended up being a delightful surprise, due to their welcoming and elegant setting as well as to their delectable savors, real delicacies for our taste buds.  Last week a friend asked me to join her for diner on the same night at a restaurant that she heard to be « amazing ». A couple of hours later we were there: The presentation of the first appetizer that was served to us was refined, however its taste did not go along the same line.  Unable to eat it, we were however still enthusiastic for the next 10 platters that were to come.  Unfortunately, the following ones were simply a series of never-ending horrors, each plate being worse than the other.  Each new one made our stomach turn, halfway through the meal my friend was ready to leave.  We stayed until the end, nonetheless, barely touching the plates that kept coming. Dessert finally arrived, after some long and painful hours: A Meringue shaped like garlic on a chocolate bed. We thought that we would finally be able to eat something decent after this horror show. We were mistaken: indeed the sweet chocolate meringue was filled with GARLIC CREAM in the inside… I would therefore not recommend this restaurant to anyone, the city has enough exquisite restaurants to not have to waste your time and money on this place.

title_review: The most unique and enjoyable restaurant experience so far.
review_preview: We went to DSTAGE to celebrate a promotion and we were not disappointed. The structure of the meal is very interesting and challenges your senses, both culinary and visually. The food is fantastic and very unique so it requires an open mind to be able...
review_full: We went to DSTAGE to celebrate a promotion and we were not disappointed. The structure of the meal is very interesting and challenges your senses, both culinary and visually. The food is fantastic and very unique so it requires an open mind to be able to fully enjoy the experience. We had the 12 dish menu and I would recommend to anyone who is considering visiting DSTAGE. Service in was excellent, our bespoke waitress was Marta and she took very good care of us. I was impressed by the knowledge that the servers have regarding the preparation of the dishes and how to best enjoy them. If you are having a bottle of wine with the meal be sure to use their sommelier service which was excellent. The interior design of the restaurant is very rustic and relaxed which set a fantastic mood. Our meal took around 3 hours. If you are visiting be sure to take your time and enjoy the experience! A big thank you to Marta, Javier and Diego for making our evening very special.

title_review: A perfect last night in Madrid
review_preview: We had booked a table on the terrace and were greeted downstairs and taken up to the terrace in an old fashioned elevator where we were greeted again and taken to our table.  It was a warm balmy night and with only about 15 tables...
review_full: We had booked a table on the terrace and were greeted downstairs and taken up to the terrace in an old fashioned elevator where we were greeted again and taken to our table. It was a warm balmy night and with only about 15 tables outside there was a lovely intimate atmosphere whilst still having plenty of space around us.  We had chosen the full tasting menu and hadn't quite known how many courses there would be, but there were at least 25 and each one was a new experience. We sat down at 9pm and finished the last course approaching midnight so it was a full night of culinary delights!  I don't want to give anything away but I will say the menu is as inventive as it is delicious and the whole meal was a wonderful and unique experience that I would recommend to anyone visiting Madrid. The service was excellent and professional, but friendly, and dishes were all explained as they came to the table including what was edible and what wasn't! (which will mean more if you go :-).  The view from the terrace was a little more limited that I had hoped as you are close to another tall building but it was still amazing to have the experience outside and it really added to the night.  If I had any criticisms at all I would say that there were a lot of soft textures in the first third of the menu and it would have been good to have more of a mix but they did come later in the menu. Also, when the menu is 135 euros a head and the waiter offers coffee at the end, I would expect to be told that this was an extra rather than discover the 6 euro per cup cost when the bill arrives.  Overall though a fantastic night of wonderful food, innovation, beauty and skill that we will remember for a long time. My favourite courses were a wonderful cappuccino desert and a stunning lobster dish - and the sweets at the end are a wonderful conclusion! Go and taste a wonderful part of our Madrid experience.

review_preview: My husband and I somehow got a same day reservation to this restaurant. I think it was fate. It was an experience to be remembered even close to a year later. The chef had recently traveled to Peru and parts of Asia so the menu...
review_full: My husband and I somehow got a same day reservation to this restaurant. I think it was fate. It was an experience to be remembered even close to a year later. The chef had recently traveled to Peru and parts of Asia so the menu was heavily influenced by his traveled. I really didn't now what to expect but it was literally deliciously amazing every step of the way. From the cocktails before dinner that's we had in the sitting area. The small bites we had while at a counter near the kitchen where we also watched the chefs prepare things we would enjoy later. We'd been enjoying as many Michelin rated restaurants as possible during our ten week trip to Spain and this was by far our favorite. Even better than the ones in Paris. So. Damn. Good. That my husband teared up during dessert and couldn't resist hugging the chef when he came to say hello.

We have chosen two tostas and two tapas to share between two and the food was plenty and, most of all, sublime in quality (you simply can't miss the salmorejo!). The service was promt and curteous and also the typical drink, Vermó, was very good. It is one of the best place we have been in our time in Madrid.

title_review: Gluten free however poor quality food
review_preview: We visited this restaurant due to the large amount of reviews discussing how great it was for gluten free dietary requirements. We had spent two weeks travelling through Spain eating amazing food and this was our last night on the trip. The restaurant is situated...
review_full: We visited this restaurant due to the large amount of reviews discussing how great it was for gluten free dietary requirements. We had spent two weeks travelling through Spain eating amazing food and this was our last night on the trip. The restaurant is situated in a basement and is very small. The majority of the menu can be prepared gluten free and the waitress was very knowledgeable which was great however, the quality of the food wasn't good. A large proportion of the menu was things on gluten free toast with the rest of it being a little more interesting but being nearly 10 euros a dish. We ordered pork, fish balls amongst other things but were very disappointed. One of our most expensive meals on the trip and most disappointing.

The "Menu di dia" is excellent value for money, and they have it all day long and also on weekends, which is a pleasant surprise. The food was good, and plenty, and the waitress was very kind and (which is not common in Madrid) spoke very good English. We went there around 7pm and found plenty of seats, as the Spanish don't go for dinner before 9pm it seems. Overall, great value for money, nice place and friendly staff, definitely recommended!

title_review: Another for the "no regrets, but wouldn't return" list.
review_preview: We paid a visit here on the strength of TripAdvisor reviews. Unfortunately, our overall experience did not match those of some of our predecessors. Firstly, the member of staff who dealt with us (and it was really only one) was excellent, very pleasant and with...
review_full: We paid a visit here on the strength of TripAdvisor reviews. Unfortunately, our overall experience did not match those of some of our predecessors. Firstly, the member of staff who dealt with us (and it was really only one) was excellent, very pleasant and with a good command of English. On arrival and throughout our visit in the late evening, it was quiet. The food, we both felt, was enjoyable and reasonable value. What let things down was the cost of Cokes, 2€ for each bottle of less than 250ml, which is extremely expensive for a bar, even in Madrid. I tend to be quite wary in venues I'm not familiar with and notice points such as this. Looking at the other reviews, perhaps we were just unlucky!

title_review: Traditional little bar, serving excellent food and wine
review_preview: Others have used the term "gem", and I think that sums this place up perfectly. It's on Calle Cava Baja – a street packed with tapas bars. But this unassuming little place is turning out excellent food and wine for the price. Dishes are fresh, tasty...
review_full: Others have used the term "gem", and I think that sums this place up perfectly. It's on Calle Cava Baja – a street packed with tapas bars. But this unassuming little place is turning out excellent food and wine for the price. Dishes are fresh, tasty and, while being rooted in tradition, are given a modern twist. The wine list is well though out, and not just limited to the typical Rioja/Ribera del Duero range. Also, excellent cavas by the glass. Stand at the marble bar, order a few plates to share, and enjoy.

We had lovely tapas here and drinks two nights and the bar lady/server/dishwasher and everything else is just lovely! We all ate the gluten free and it was good usually we only leave it for her but it tasted so good we all enjoyed it. The price was the same for gluten free as well which is most unusual. Cheap food and drinks, interesting atmosphere and a great vibe. Highly recommend. There were three other places recommended on the tapas gluten free circuit but don't bother as one is closed and the other two had no idea what we were on about!!! This is the one and only!!!!

It was fantastic value for money: 5 tapas, three beers and two wines cost just over €50.

review_preview: This taberna is AMAZING! It's a small place, with a little bar upstairs and seating downstairs. Looks quite basic but don't let that put you off! The tapas here is the best I have ever tasted. So much so that we visited twice whilst on...
review_full: This taberna is AMAZING! It's a small place, with a little bar upstairs and seating downstairs. Looks quite basic but don't let that put you off! The tapas here is the best I have ever tasted. So much so that we visited twice whilst on a 5 night break in Madrid.  On our 1st visit the taberna was full so we went for a drink and came back later, as Beatriz (the manager/owner) said she would have a table in about 30 mins. We are so glad we returned!! Beatriz remembered us and was genuinely pleased to see us. We were so hungry, having not eaten since breakfast, that we started ordering numerous dishes from the tapas menu. Beatriz was very helpful and suggested that 4 would suffice, but we could order more later if we were still hungry - which we did, as the food was so delicious.  On leaving we said we would return on another night and we were pleasantly surprised that when we did Beatriz remembered us again. She was just as helpful, friendly and cheerful as our 1st visit. Again, the food was delicious. Chicken red curry is a must order, although we cannot fault anything as all the dishes were beautiful. House wine is lovely too! We also received complimentary bread on both evenings, in addition to a mini dessert and drink with the bill. So kind and so thoughtful. Beatriz really looked after us and made us feel so welcome, it didn't feel like it was any effort on her behalf - we can't thank her enough!  We had two fantastic evenings here and will definitely be returning when we go back to Madrid.

review_preview: Taberna la Concha was highly praised in TripAdvisor and it was number #2 restaurant from Madrid. It was also in the next block where we were staying so I was really waiting to go there. So, what did we get? Very typical Spanish tapas -...
review_full: Taberna la Concha was highly praised in TripAdvisor and it was number #2 restaurant from Madrid. It was also in the next block where we were staying so I was really waiting to go there. So, what did we get? Very typical Spanish tapas - muy típico - in the cellar with clinical lightning. The wine, ribera, was alright, and so was the hummus, but the pimientas con queso was, to be honest, quite lousy. Special racion for vegetarians, they advertise. I’ve been in dozens of better vegetarian restaurants and what Concha offered was also very typical Spanish vegetarian food where you just put some vegetable and cheese instead of jamon. If you want to visit Concha you are free to do so, but I am asking why don't you just visit any other bar/taberna from Cava Baja or La Latina? And there are dozens of them with equal or better quality with the same price. If you want to eat excellent vegetarian food I highly recommend to visit Viva la Vida which is only few blocks away.

title_review: Small Bar, Great Staff, Very good value for money
review_preview: We stayed in an apartment directly above the bar.  The bar is small but has a really good vibe due to the enthusiasm of the staff.   Delimer, the lady in charge, does not speak English but spends her time welcoming people in a way that...
review_full: We stayed in an apartment directly above the bar. The bar is small but has a really good vibe due to the enthusiasm of the staff. Delimer, the lady in charge, does not speak English but spends her time welcoming people in a way that surmounts language barriers. Free tapas is the norm and the quality of the food and drinks is very good and at very reasonable prices. We ate in the bar on two nights and used it as a local when we returned from our sightseeing in Madrid. A special mention for Andrew who is Russian. He speaks very good English and acted as interpreter with the rest of the staff. We ate in a number of what might be called quality establishments but none of them had as good a 'feel good' factor as the H10-Bar Huertas

review_preview: What is it about me and pitta bread?  I ordered hummus to start at H10 Bar, which was very nice, but there was not enough pitta bread to scoop this up.  maybe it's me and I should slap it on the bread, who knows, but...
review_full: What is it about me and pitta bread? I ordered hummus to start at H10 Bar, which was very nice, but there was not enough pitta bread to scoop this up. maybe it's me and I should slap it on the bread, who knows, but I always seem to never have enough. This was the only downside of a pleasant visit. I also had Ensalada Burrata, which was OK, but I am not sure if the mozzarella was buffalo, I have certainly had creamier and lighter. My wife had Lomo, goats cheese and cameralised onions on toast. This was nice and well presented but the onions could have been sweeter through more cameralisation. The service was welcoming and all staff had a friendly smile and a nice word for us throughout our meal. This is a good place and well worth visiting but a few tweaks would have meant a very good rating.

review_preview: The name reflects the concept of the restaurant:  sitting at different locations with different presentations - essentially a theatrical performance.  We have been to many wonderful tastings with delicious food, but few are also exciting.   From the moment you walk in the door you can...
review_full: The name reflects the concept of the restaurant: sitting at different locations with different presentations - essentially a theatrical performance. We have been to many wonderful tastings with delicious food, but few are also exciting. From the moment you walk in the door you can expect the unexpected. The waitstaff explain each unique course and how to eat them to extract the greatest flavors. Though the combinations of foods are unusual, the tastes are sensational. Each course is served on one of a kind dishware, designed for the course. I suggest the wine pairing, particularly if you are a party of two. We are small eaters so we ordered the 10 course meal, but could easily have had the 14 courses. We were there a couple of months ago and are still talking about our experience. If you love food, don't miss Dstage.

Luckily, La Concha saved the day (or rather, several days!). This is a quaint little restaurant with delicious tapas that you don't see on other menus (i.e., foie gras and lentil stew). They had a separate gluten free menu and they served you gluten free bread on the side. We ordered several rounds of tapas and the restaurant was so busy I was afraid they would forget that we were gluten free and accidentally serve us our tapas on top of regular bread. However, I saw the kitchen staff announce to the server/bartender every time our order was ready "sin gluten", so that was a relief. As other people have stated, this restaurant is small and gets busy very quickly, but the service is still fast and friendly. A great go-to restaurant for those who have Celiac.

title_review: Not quite as good as the reviews has us believe...
review_preview: Visted La Concha after reading all the Tripadvisor reviews - we didn't have a reservation and weren't able to get a table straight away, instead we put our names down with the very welcoming waitress and went to a nearby bar for a drink, coming...
review_full: Visted La Concha after reading all the Tripadvisor reviews - we didn't have a reservation and weren't able to get a table straight away, instead we put our names down with the very welcoming waitress and went to a nearby bar for a drink, coming back around half an hour later. When we arrived back we were taken downstairs to the restaurant area which is very stripped back and casual - and not really what we were expecting. Still we assumed the food was what was the draw and that's what we were looking forward to trying. We ordered about 7 or 8 dishes between 2 of us and the waitress was very helpful suggesting things to order - she also let us know we'd ordered plenty and she wasn't wrong! Food wise we had some cold and hot tapas dishes, it all started very well with some very delicious cold tapas dishes, the tower of mozzarella and tomato was lovely as was the cured beef and parmesan but as we moved onto the hot dishes things started to go a bit downhill. The meatballs were awful (the couple on the table next to us didn't touch theirs and we couldn't understand why...until ours arrived.). The prawn toast wasn't great either and the thai fish balls were only ok. The bill was cheap but I don't think we left particularly satisfied and I wouldn't recommend this place to other people visiting Madrid, purely because it was too hit and miss with each dish. Shame as the reviews on here were great...perhaps we were in on an off night?

review_preview: I was very excited to try this place, after having dined at Diego Guerrero's excellent previous venue - Club Allard. I had heard that he was trying to create a new, more informal place where he could experiment further with combinations of ingredients and flavors...
review_full: I was very excited to try this place, after having dined at Diego Guerrero's excellent previous venue - Club Allard. I had heard that he was trying to create a new, more informal place where he could experiment further with combinations of ingredients and flavors from far away places, and the result shows the effort that has gone into investigating and preparing the menu. I will not spoil the surprise by describing the menu here - part of the experience is letting your senses try to discover what each dish is made from, and savoring the different tastes that each course delivers in each mouthful. I will say that the attention to presentation is as detailed as to the taste, and that the service was outstanding. I enjoy a bit of banter with the waiters as long as they know how far you want to go, but they were always extremely professional.  The venue itself was very appealing to me - no sign outside, an industrial, almost loft-like space with bare brick, cast iron large window frames and an intimate atmosphere created by the lighting. You will be invited to enjoy a cocktail at the bar upon arrival, before being moved to the kitchen area and then to your table. At each place you will be served a piece of art. It will be (more or less) explained to you depending on how much they want you to be surprised. Remember, this is not just dining, it is a dining experience, so enjoy it!

review_preview: No wonder this is so difficult to get a booking here. Just 2 large tables and 4 smaller ones and a mysterious private dining room is all there is. And it's not really a terrace. It's an air conditioned room overlooking the inside courtyard of...
review_full: No wonder this is so difficult to get a booking here. Just 2 large tables and 4 smaller ones and a mysterious private dining room is all there is. And it's not really a terrace. It's an air conditioned room overlooking the inside courtyard of this private club but all the better for that in the summer heat of Madrid. Beware that the dress code for gents is a suit jacket, but it would seem that you can wear what you like as long as you have the jacket on. When we went, there was a group of Spanish men with jeans and trainers on but all with the obligatory jacket! Never mind, at least they didn't insist on a tie like in some of the more stuffier establishments in the UK.  Although Ferran had some part of the restaurant in the past he's well and truly gone now earning squillions as an international ambassador for Telefonica. In my opinion, no food experience could ever match El Bulli so there's no point in trying, but the Casino certainly still had his influence.  We had the smaller tasting menu for lunch as we were sampling Club Allard later that day and didn't want to over-face ourselves.  It was absolutely brilliant. From the Blumenthal-style cocktail made with liquid nitrogen at the start to the final dessert course everything was perfect. So was the service. Just simply faultless. Other reviewers have gone into enough detail on the actual dishes and there's no point in repeating them but I would simply say that if you are a lover of this style of food and you're in Madrid, you've simply GOT to be there.  And if you don't happen to be in Madrid, make a booking and arrange a trip.  It really is that good.

title_review: A real treat in creative cuisine
review_preview: My wife and I celebrated an occasion at DStage, and enjoyed every minute of it. We made reservations a month in advance, and were contacted th day before to consult with about particular tastes and allergies. The restaurant serves two versions of a tasting menu,...
review_full: My wife and I celebrated an occasion at DStage, and enjoyed every minute of it. We made reservations a month in advance, and were contacted th day before to consult with about particular tastes and allergies. The restaurant serves two versions of a tasting menu, we took the short version, which left us more than satisfied. There are some interesting features on how the food is served that are better left as a surprise, so I will not elaborate. The sequence of dishes was remarkable in flavor, presentation and creativity, with the right doses of irony and trompe l'oeil. Some dishes were re-interpreted Spanish classics, others were flights of fantasy, others were composed of very unusual and interesting ingredients. A meal to remember! The restaurant has been open only for a year, so I expect the crowds to be soon be clamoring for Michelin to bestow their shining stars. Service was excellent, and really welcomed in a city that has a long way to go in terms of service. The room was simple, with Scandinavian and industrial chic tones. Overall, a superb experience that is up to pair with any celebration. The tab was 206€ with several drinks by the glass. Bottom line: save up, line up and eat up!

review_preview: We had MANY wonderful meals in Spain, but our best dining experience was at La Terraza del Casino de Madrid!  The restaurant is housed in a private club (casino) that is so visually stunning that it makes it worth the visit in and of itself....
review_full: We had MANY wonderful meals in Spain, but our best dining experience was at La Terraza del Casino de Madrid! The restaurant is housed in a private club (casino) that is so visually stunning that it makes it worth the visit in and of itself. Like Per Se and 11 Madison Park, the chef prepares unexpected delights that just keep coming! Unlike these "tasting menu" restaurants, however, you get to actually choose your courses as you would in more traditional restaurants. In short, you get the best of both worlds...the chef's flights of fancy combined with a dinner you select yourself without being subjected to the tyranny of the kitchen! Dinner for two was less than three hundred dollars, as opposed to the $700.-$800. you would pay for a comparable meal in NYC. The service was relaxed, friendly, unpretentious and perfect! I do suggest, however, that you confirm your reservation before you go. We reserved through our hotel (Hotel Ritz, Madrd) and both we and the concierge wrote down the date and time. When we arrived, we were turned away by a rather frosty Maitre D' who scolded us for not showing up the day before. We were turned away. Returning to the hotel, the concierge argued to get us back in, but the Maitre D' was put out for most of meal. There was NO ONE waiting for a table. This did not ruin the meal, but best to check your reservation to avoid any inconvenience and embarrassment. Also, tipping can be different in Spain because they often do not allow you to put your tip on your credit card. Tips are left in cash or they will awkwardly make a separate bill for your tip. Best to check tipping policies in Spain, which tend to be different than they are in the USA and other parts of Europe. The restaurant is wonderful....don't miss it!

review_preview: We had a wonderful dinner here beginning with a warm welcome and the first amuse bouche of sea urchin in citric dashi at the bar. The second amuse bouche of shrimp ceviche was served at the kitchen counter. Both solid ways to start our meal....
review_full: We had a wonderful dinner here beginning with a warm welcome and the first amuse bouche of sea urchin in citric dashi at the bar. The second amuse bouche of shrimp ceviche was served at the kitchen counter. Both solid ways to start our meal. We were then led to our table for the formal start of the tasting menu, which was full of delights and surprises. All were strong courses individually, but together, they flowed beautifully from start to finish. The stand-out dishes were the 'Peking Duck' (duck liver parfait sandwiched between roasted dehydrated duck skin crisps, tastes like peking duck, but texturally entirely different - in a word, genius!) and the roast octopus.  The wine match was fantastic and good value. Service was excellent, and whilst the level of English varied, everyone made an effort to explain everything in as much detail as they could. You could feel the passion in everyone's work, with no pretension in sight. In short, this is a top dining experience, run by a young, passionate & dynamic team, deserving of at least 2-3 Michelin stars. We have dined at 3 Michelin star places which fall short of this amazing experience.

review_preview: This restaurant was recommended to me as one of the top eating establishments in Madrid. I was excited, for the first few minutes, but this rapidly disintegrated into disappointment and disbelief. The location is certainly impressive, and the staff are attentive and courteous. The reverence...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended to me as one of the top eating establishments in Madrid. I was excited, for the first few minutes, but this rapidly disintegrated into disappointment and disbelief.  The location is certainly impressive, and the staff are attentive and courteous. The reverence given to the food however was almost risible. It is certainly adventurous, with some interesting combinations of unusual flavours (which do not always work), but nouvelle cuisine of a kind I have not seen for many years, the stuff of farcical comedy sketches - tiny toothpaste tubes of insipid sauces for one to pour on tiny, tasteless rolls of pastry, a miniscule chocolate served as an avant-garde amuse bouche journeying from the kitchen to my table as the lone inhabitant of a vast white plate on an even vaster silver platter... and when my main course finally arrived it too was on the leaner side of meagre .. as well as the colder side of tepid. I asked for a good red wine, but what arrived was mediocre and freezing cold - I know that this is often how red wine is served in Spain but it is not really to my taste, and when a heartier alternative at room temperature was politely requested, another iced version arrived. Had anyone listened to what I had said? The food is expensive - this was to be expected - but at this price and this level of surgeon-like attention to presentation and delivery something a little bit more special was expected. I had been looking for a rather special place to take some rather special guests in a few weeks. Suffice to say, I shall be looking elsewhere

Chef Diego Guerrero is adventurous, happy to experiment and eager to create a different dining experience. We opted for the 90 euro tasting menu and weren't disappointed. Irritations? Some questions we asked about the food, and the way it was prepared, were lost in translation - but the staff are young and learning the trade themselves. Also the a couple of the accompanying wines, while different, didn't quite work for us. The best was an Argentine Malbec. But Diego is selling the 'experience' as much as the food and it is a meal you remember. A restaurant worth its Michelin star.

review_full: We went to DStage for our anniversary and thoroughly enjoyed the evening. They have it very well choreographed where you start with a drink and your first dish while relaxing in the lounge, then you go back to see the kitchen and have another course, then they take you to your seat for the remaining dishes. The food was really unique and each plate was like a piece of art. They were accommodating for our various likes/dislikes in terms of ingredients. Most of the tables are situated so you see the kitchen and all the chefs working. It is fascinating. The main difference between this and other fine dining places with prix fix menus is that this is very hip and relaxed and doesn't take itself too seriously. They also brought out a special dessert for our anniversary which was sweet. It was a perfect special occasion restaurant.

title_review: The culinary experience of a lifetime
review_preview: Most pictures don’t do right to the complexity of the dish itself. DStage is a guaranteed night out you’ll remember. Though it can boast two Michelin stars, the interior will make you feel at home straight away. It has all the lofty Scandinavian elements and...
review_full: Most pictures don’t do right to the complexity of the dish itself. DStage is a guaranteed night out you’ll remember. Though it can boast two Michelin stars, the interior will make you feel at home straight away. It has all the lofty Scandinavian elements and adds a warm patio feeling to it. The kitchen runs like clockwork and dishes are served at an ideal pace. Service is impeccable and friendly. The sommelier will gladly introduce you to his rich local organic oeuvre. Each dish is elegantly simple and sometimes on the verge of one’s comfort zone but never beyond. Estimate to pay about 200€ for the 18 course menu, including cocktail, 4 glasses of wine, water, thea and digestives.

title_review: An absolute pleasure for all the senses!
review_preview: OMG! This has got to be the the best restaurant ever. We went to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary and it was a toss up between going there or to the Goya restaurant at the Ritz. How relieved and pleased with ourselves were we that...
review_full: OMG! This has got to be the the best restaurant ever. We went to celebrate our 25th wedding anniversary and it was a toss up between going there or to the Goya restaurant at the Ritz. How relieved and pleased with ourselves were we that we chose this heaven for the taste buds.  PLEASE do not go if you are not adventurous, to deny them full marks for your lack of culinary perception would be nothing less than a criminal act. For those who are less faint hearted, jump on board and enjoy the roller-coaster ride of ideas and inspirations that will confuse and rock your palate as never before. The service, the ambience, the food is second to none, and should be experienced at least once in your life. I'm hoping it won't be the only time for me.

review_preview: Molecular gastronomy dining is not new to me! But this was so beautiful that I was thinking about the food on my flight back from Madrid! I was remembering how it went by so fast and wished it lasted longer! For the welcome drink they...
review_full: Molecular gastronomy dining is not new to me! But this was so beautiful that I was thinking about the food on my flight back from Madrid! I was remembering how it went by so fast and wished it lasted longer! For the welcome drink they had Pasco-sour which was made in front of us. Apart from the gimmick-ey liquid nitrogen (which was nice) - the lime was so so so sweet and smooth!! It just melted and the Pisco liquor was perfect addition! We tried the short tasting menu. We had anchovies in Vinegar, potato with ali-oli and sphereified olives. The potato was alright but the olives was lovely the way the flavor burst in my mouth! The Olive oil frozen toast with olive oil shuffle and olive oil cheese was okay. I loved loved the spicy popcorn and anaconda cone!! I wanted more!! I don't remember the mackerel Vietnamese roll to be honest. The white sea bass Tiraditos was really good. It was served on a piece of lime you had to bite on to. It was really good. Next was the Thai peanut. It was a peanut shaped shell made out of peanut flavor and inside was Thai curry flavors and coconut. It was short and sweet and really good. I love the presentation. The shrimp Omelette was a hit on the table. I was okay with it. It was a crispy and had small shrimp on it.  For the main course, we had the frozen gazpacho canapé. Which is alright. To be honest, I don't remember the almond vichyssoise, Dublin bay prawn, tomato and red mullet with mayo tout. The creamy rice yogurt, cockles, lemon was nice. The rack of suckling pig was really really good. The texture of the meat was great.  The palette cleanser was so so so pretty. The center section of the rose was removed and balsamic flavored red pieces we placed in between. They looked part of the rose. I can't imagine to say the beauty of the this dish.  The dessert was various components of citrus. I was plated well. I tasted good. But not the most memorable dish I have had.  I ordered the sheep milk cheese cake separately. This was not a typical cheese cake but it was smooth serving of sheep milk cheese. This was smooth and really really good. I could not finish it cause I was really full by then. We ordered the San Amato 2012 and 904 Gran Riserva 2001. I loved the wine. It was smooth.

title_review: Surprises and supreme attention to detail at every turn
review_preview: Dstage does not disappoint. It knocks you out. It is the first restaurant I've been to where I genuinely worry about giving away spoilers. With this in mind,  I'd recommend NOT looking at the numerous photos online. The visual surprises are a key part of...
review_full: Dstage does not disappoint. It knocks you out. It is the first restaurant I've been to where I genuinely worry about giving away spoilers. With this in mind, I'd recommend NOT looking at the numerous photos online. The visual surprises are a key part of the experience.  The staff are warm and friendly. Dishes are explained in detail (at least in Spanish, can't speak for the English translation) and the service is faultless. Glasses are refilled with almost telepathic efficiency - wine bottles don't stay on the table. Especially of note was that the staff made the effort to ask if we'd viisted before - and when - and adjusted the menu as a result. The 8 course tasting menu, with a distinct Japanese/Latin American feel to it, actually extends to 13 dishes from arriving at the bar to finishing the dessert and is a stream of constant surprises. Ingredients - indeed whole dishes - you've eaten before in your life look completely new but may yet taste brilliantly familiar. Things you've never seen or even heard of are often spectacular, eye-opening discoveries.  So Dtsage is a culinary adventure. Approach with an open mind and you will not be disappointed in anyway whatsoever. Finally, ask for a table facing the kitchen if you want to observe the artistic precision of Diego and his team in progress.

review_preview: DSTAgE was the first restaurant reservation I made for our trip to Spain and it was our last meal in Madrid. It makes me sad thinking about it. I wish I could go back in time and experience it all over again. I guess we...
review_full: DSTAgE was the first restaurant reservation I made for our trip to Spain and it was our last meal in Madrid. It makes me sad thinking about it. I wish I could go back in time and experience it all over again. I guess we left the best for last. I love the fact that many restaurants in Spain served the same menu at lunch time as they did dinner time. I know in NYC some restaurants offer that but in LA it is all about dinner. DSTAgE means “Days to Smell Taste Amaze Grow & Enjoy”. Chef Diego Guerrero left the two Michelin star restaurant, El Club Allard in 2013 to open up this restaurant last summer. In less than one year they earned their first Michelin star. The restaurant looked industrial with exposed brick and hardwood floor. I guess he wanted the emphasis to be on the food. Upon entering the restaurant a staff member checks your name on the list and invites you to seat at the bar area. You can have a drink and they serve you the first course . You are then taken to the open kitchen area where one of the chefs prepares your next course. After that, you are seated in the dining room. They have two tasting menus: DTASTE, with 10 creations, for 88 Euros, and DSTAgE, with 13 creations, for 118 Euros. We went for the shorter one and it was plenty of food. This must have been the most interactive restaurant experience we have ever had. A couple of the dishes with many steps were prepared in front of you. The servers/cooks were friendly and spoke English but at times we smiled when our waitress introduced every dish with, “I made this and that”. As I made an eye contact with Chef Diego Guerrero, he came over and I thanked him for the wonderful experience we had. He seemed very friendly and humble. we had the following courses: Sea Urchin & Citric Dashi As soon as I saw this dish, I knew we were in for a treat. I love uni and this was not only visually stunning, but tasted great also. The only problem was you wanted more of it, much more. King Prawn Ceviche This was like having a personal chef preparing an amazing dish for you. Every time I wanted to snap a picture, he added more ingredients to the dish. He first mixed the king prawn on the top of a himalayan salt slab. He then placed it on a strip of banana leaf and added all kind of garnishes. You were instructed to hold it like a cigar and drop it in your mouth like an oyster. Huitlacoche Mochi Interesting fusion of Latin and Asian. Quinoa Bread When our waitress mentioned quinoa bread, I was like What? Of Course I wanted to try it. I have never had quinoa bread before and found it nutty and dense. Now I have to find a recipe and make my own. How creative of them to come up with that. Tuna, Toffee & “Foiesabi” This was a surf and turf dish. Tuna and foie gras plus toffee for sweetness and crunch. A nice dish. Octopus roasted with “Tomatillo” We love octopus and enjoyed this dish. Tolosa Bean Ravioli with Cabbage Broth This dish was amazing. Who knew beans could taste so heavenly. The cabbage broth almost tasted like dashi. From Winter to Spring As you can see there was a big production for this dish and was very interactive. Torching and mixing all kind of exotic ingredients from around the globe. It tasted sensational. Red Mullet braised with Saffron Sauce and Crispy Scales A nice light dish. “The Butcher’s Cut” This must have been the first beef dish we had in Spain because we all know how much Spanish love their pork. Not only the presentation was original and imaginative, the beef tasted out of this world. Maji Leaf After that heavenly beef this was a nice refreshing treat. Popcorn with Strawberries and Sweet Egg Yolk I liked the strawberries more than the popcorn and loved the presentation. Purple Garlic A meringue filled with black garlic cream was a nice ending to a wonderful lunch. Now, I have to go and wipe off my tears!! You can see the pictures at: https://travel4foodnart.wordpress.com/2015/06/26/dstage/

review_preview: This is one very strange restaurant. It is part of a private club in one of the NH Hotels. Security was a bit overly enthusiastic in terms of even letting us in, although we had reservations made well in advance. We dined inside, not on...
review_full: This is one very strange restaurant.  It is part of a private club in one of the NH Hotels. Security was a bit overly enthusiastic in terms of even letting us in, although we had reservations made well in advance.  We dined inside, not on the terrace, but that made little difference because the issues that quickly surfaced have nothing to do with service, ambiance or décor. They lie in what is going on in the kitchen and in the mind of the chef. Selecting this as our third top-level dinner in a week in Madrid was a mistake. We had previous dined at Goya in The Ritz Hotel and Zalacain and were impressed by both. But, imagine going to what you think is going to be a top notch experience and leaving, as one previous reviewer put it, “feeling a little sick.” Not sick just because we’d spent over $500 US on what turned out to be little more than a disconnected array of amuse bouche dishes, but also because these little tapas tidbits were just short of being terrible in terms of taste and did not mesh in any way we could identify.  This was an assembly of odds and ends, leading up to the final dish of rabbit cevit, which, in our opinion, was nothing special.  Coherence among this many items would seem to be essential if the diner is to come away with some sort of conclusion other than that the chef is doing his own thing.  Some of the minute dishes were fine: the ‘mackerel teriyaki,’ ‘lobster with olive oil soup’ and ‘Monkfish with celeriac puree and chick pea comsomme’ were quite good, but most of the rest of the twenty some tiny servings were garishly cute and not especially tasty either, at least not to our reasonably sophisticated palates. (Over 40 years, we have enjoyed many meals prepared by Europe’s and Asia’s top chefs and never felt so put off as we did here.)  Almost everything we tasted was loaded with salt. I sent one dish, a mixture of mozzarella, anchovies and basil jelly, back as being beyond my limit for sodium. Desserts were fine, but again, nothing exceptional. Service however, was embarrassingly fine. Our waiter worked hard bringing out and explaining dish after dish and we ate and commented hopefully, but in the end, service cannot supplant great taste experiences and a coherence among the different textures and ingredients served. The wine list was large and impressive, but we elected to have the sommelier match three wines for us with the dishes. He struck out with his first offering, a sherry that, from our non-Spanish perspective, didn’t work with anything we were served. His second wine was a white neither of us could identify with and so I requested that he select a Spanish sparkling wine, a moderately priced cava. It was satisfactory, more or less, although grossly overpriced, but I think that by then they had lost us.  Finally, I think there is a difference between demonstrating creativity and just being cute. Two examples: (1) A tiny tartlet with some non-descript contents was served with a small pharmaceutical-style tube of unidentified contents. We were told to open the tube and squirt the contents onto the tart. Other than a very salty flavor, there was nothing to this. (2) A so-called ‘Kellogg’s Paella’ involved a clear plastic package of enhanced Kellogg’s Rice Krispies cereal that we were instructed to add to a small demitasse cup of mediocre seafood bisque. Halfway through this, we were told to add a single tiny, seemingly raw baby prawn, (what we call ‘popcorn shrimp’ at home), and then squeeze a clear plastic tube of some glop into the mixture. The result? Glop. Cute. Pointless, expensive nonsense.  Observation: much of what was served was finger food, yet we were never offered so much as a damp napkin to clean our fingers or hands before or throughout the meal. Another reviewer mentioned “The emperor’s new clothes,” in an analogy to what is going on here and that fits well. Madrid has so much going for it, its a shame that this sham is allowed to continue based on a Michelin stars award. Incidentally, they made a big deal about having a dress code that specifies a coat for men. We dressed formally, as we often do, but saw diners who were wearing street clothes with what would hardly pass for a dress or business jacket. Why have a code if it is not enforced? Our tab, with two tasting menu ‘dinners’ and a mid range bottle of cava was about $525US. No thanks, we will not be going back.

review_preview: Having had a really fine meal at our hotel, the Ritz, the night before, we we looking forward to the tasting menu. It was one of the worst meals we have ever had. Pretentious, badly balanced and we left feeling slightly sick. The appetizers were...
review_full: Having had a really fine meal at our hotel, the Ritz, the night before, we we looking forward to the tasting menu. It was one of the worst meals we have ever had. Pretentious, badly balanced and we left feeling slightly sick. The appetizers were uninspiring, and too salty. The fish dishes were insipid and the borsht was underwhelming. We asked the chef Paco Roncero to come out and he didn't seem too concerned - neither did the staff. Our meal, it turned out, was sponsored by Abrau Dursu - a Russian sparkling wine - which was undrinkable. Quite how this place managed to hold on to its Michelin stars, I have no idea. Avoid. Avoid. Avoid. Needless to say we were charged the full price of 108 Euros pp.

title_review: creative cooking but need more focus on taste
review_preview: The view, service, and style were all very impressive in this restaurant. this is definitely a special place to go for romantic dates. The food was cooked well and the restaurant used a lot of liquid nitrogen to cook/prepare various dishes but somehow it felt...
review_full: The view, service, and style were all very impressive in this restaurant. this is definitely a special place to go for romantic dates. The food was cooked well and the restaurant used a lot of liquid nitrogen to cook/prepare various dishes but somehow it felt more showy than getting down to what was important...the taste of the food. Please don't get me wrong, the food was good but just did not perform on par with the ambiance, design and service. Maybe the restaurant performed the other aspects so well that it took away from the food or built up the expectations way too high and only to miss the mark on what restaurants truly suppose to do which is to deliver exceptional food. If they can top off the food, then they will be great. Cost for the dinner - 200 euro per person.

review_preview: We chose DSTAGE after reading the positive Trip Advisor reviews. We tried to book on-line 3 months prior to our visit but only one time slot was available among  our 8 days' stay in Madrid. It is therefore advisable to make reservation early enough. We...
review_full: We chose DSTAGE after reading the positive Trip Advisor reviews. We tried to book on-line 3 months prior to our visit but only one time slot was available among our 8 days' stay in Madrid. It is therefore advisable to make reservation early enough. We were glad that we had the chance of tasting the superb 10 platos menu. Upon entering the restaurant, we were warmly greeted, escorted to the bar and offered refreshing mocktail made of lemon, ginger and green apple. There we were served the first course, razor clam. We were then led to the open kitchen, where we had the second course, king prawn ceviche tossed on Himalayan salt board with Austrailan finger lime. Afterwards we were comfortably seated at our table to take the rest of the courses. We thoroughly enjoyed every dish. The salmon barbel, tolosa bean ravioli and slow cooked beef were to die for. The popcorn ice-cream dessert was spectacular. DSTAGE truly demonstrates high degree of culinary art and creativity. Must try in Madrid!

review_preview: The dinner started off with 4 staff members greeting us at the entrance. It turned out that the service was poor, staff never showed a smile and was not friendly at all. Gimmicky dishes in interesting containers and utensils had a deceiving look. Most of...
review_full: The dinner started off with 4 staff members greeting us at the entrance. It turned out that the service was poor, staff never showed a smile and was not friendly at all.  Gimmicky dishes in interesting containers and utensils had a deceiving look. Most of the dishes were excessively salty. It was alright to use ingredients with saltiness like seaweed but it was unacceptable when the sauce that came with it was even saltier and dehydrated the tongue. Some dishes were alright, like the rose pepper. It tasted so heavy and so concentrated. Among the hot dishes, the beef with some smoky aroma tasted the best. Though still a bit salty, the beef was juicy, tender and flavourful. We were doubtful after the first few dishes. Our suspicion was proved to be right when each dish came.  Finally, we made it to the palette-cleansing plate, which was quite refreshing. Though we joked that the desserts might be salty as well, we were so shocked when they actually were. Fermented strawberry that went with brine solution failed to impress.  To be fair, the popcorn icecream that was served inside a huge marshmallow was great. Also, sweetness of the marshmallow was well balanced by the salty and sour seasoning powder. It was the best dish of the night. It was a relief to pay and leave. So sad that we leave Madrid with such a bad last memory.

title_review: Amazing, expensive, remarkable, expensive.  Glad we went.
review_preview: So, it seems that gourmet food is like any other rare commodity.  To get a better than average experience, you need to pay more.  But at the margins, at the right hand extreme of the bell curve of excellence, well, costs increase dramatically. There are...
review_full: So, it seems that gourmet food is like any other rare commodity. To get a better than average experience, you need to pay more. But at the margins, at the right hand extreme of the bell curve of excellence, well, costs increase dramatically. There are very few establishments occupying that territory, and our lunch service was full, so clearly there are enough folks willing to pay big time, for a big-time culinary treat. I'll try to do this place justice. I won't cover every course, I lost track at 21. The wine parings made losing track quite easy.  Service: Starched shirt, military discipline, snap-to service. Yet friendly, welcoming and jovial. Perfect. Service can easily get over the top. It can intrude or frustrate. Achieving perfect service is really hard. This was perfect. Watch the eyes of everyone who works here. They are CONSTANTLY but casually scanning the room for any hint of something amiss, a need not met. A head nod at anyone gets instant attention. The hierarchy here works so well, you don't see it. Example, a plate needs removing, and the sommelier happens to be the closest person, then the sommelier jumps to action and buses. No problem. Awesome service. Best I have ever seen. Effortlessly bilingual for those who may not speak Spanish.  Location and ambience: Walk into this place and you know you're going to get something special, from the greeter at the Casino's front desk, to service at the elevator, this place exudes class. The dining room is lively, bright, quiet and fresh. No need to whisper, no need to shout. Decor is whimsical (first time I've ever used that word in a review). Lovely place. Food: We ordered the long menu. I ordered wine parings. Can't cheap out now. Best food I've ever had? That's tough. Was everyone of the 21 (I think) courses the best of its kind that I've had? No, a couple fell short. But then there were the many, many others that were transformative. Is it possible to get the entire taste of Italy in one bite? Yes, it is. With a bite sized pizza that utterly, utterly captured Italy. A teeny taco that again, utterly captured Mexican cuisine in one bite. In one bite. Foamed calamari that may have been the best thing I have ever tasted. Ever. Full stop. And on and on and on.  After a few courses, we were approached and asked if we wanted to take part in an "investigation". Why yes, of course! We were then taken down the elevator to a mysteriously lit kitchen with a long counter. We were told where to stand, in order to investigate the olive oils of Spain. Little imitation olives that instantly melted in the mouth, were the start. Then, an oven was opened and a small loaf of bread produced. Three bowls of oil were placed in front of us for dipping and experimenting with flavour. The oils were awesome, of course. But my family agreed the bread, made with oil, was the best bread we had ever eaten. How on earth did they achieve that? Then, whisked back to our tables where lunch resumed. Lunch was four hours. It seemed like one, maybe two. Desserts were beautiful. A special surprise awaits at the end of dessert. I won't reveal the plot. Wine parings went from kinda funky at the start, in my view, to out of this world near the end. Course, wine always gets better with more use doesn't it?  We consumed a vast amount of food. Vast. But we left just pleasantly full, not bloated, not uncomfortable. It takes skill to gorge people like this place does, and not let them feel gorged.  Then, it was over. And we were left alone to ponder what had just happened. The bill only came when we asked for it. It came in a lovely silver box; which I believe I should own after seeing the bill. How much? I won't be vulgar. But lunch for three was many hundreds of Euros. Many, many.  I don't know if we'll be back. Madrid is far away for us. But will we forget this meal? Never. Was it "worth it"? Is a million-dollar work of art by a master artist "worth it"? Who knows, it costs what it costs. It was a pretty penny for this family. But when a family can spend four hours talking, laughing, gasping, experiencing the very high heights of gastronomy - and making indelible memories, well, that's priceless.

The wait staff was polite, available without being fawning, and took great care to explain everything we ate. Oh, a meal to never forget.

title_review: The Worst Overpriced Meal We have Ever Had
review_preview: My husband and I booked a dinner reservation at La Terrazzoadel Casino after much research and consideration.  We have eaten at some of the best restaurants in the world, and after reading the reviews of this restaurant, we decided to give it a try.  This...
review_full: My husband and I booked a dinner reservation at La Terrazzoadel Casino after much research and consideration. We have eaten at some of the best restaurants in the world, and after reading the reviews of this restaurant, we decided to give it a try. This was literally the worst meal we have ever had. Dinner was off to a promising start with a "welcome drink," but quickly went downhill. Almost every cuisine consisted of a cold, pungent fish dish where we were told, "don't worry, the spine is edible," and please, "eat the fish head." We opted for the full tasting menu. All dishes were minuscule and most were disgusting...when we received a bland tasting item, we considered ourselves lucky. My husband and I literally had to coax each other to eat everything so we did not look rude. The service was impeccable and the staff very nice. The food, however, was terrible. After spending $500 we then went to McDonalds ( I kid you not) to get a burger and fries because we were still hungry and felt the need to wipe the entire experience from our minds...we are still having nightmares about bone marrow and fish spines.

We had the taster menu, which was one gastronomic delight after another. The creativity and attention to detail was unbelievable. review_preview: My family stopped in for an early dinner two days ago during our last evening in Madrid before flying home to the US.  What a cute discovery!  My wife had the ravioli, and my son had the pulpo (octopus), both of which were very well...
review_full: My family stopped in for an early dinner two days ago during our last evening in Madrid before flying home to the US. What a cute discovery! My wife had the ravioli, and my son had the pulpo (octopus), both of which were very well made. The highlight item, however, was the sangria. It was so refreshing and smooth, and it was certainly the best sangria we had over 2 weeks in Spain. I think the secret was the addition of a little vermouth. The best part of the experience was that the owner was so friendly! She patiently accepted my poor Spanish, and it was such great fun talking to her about each others lives and backgrounds. Her sister even came out from the kitchen to talk with my wife, son, and me! It was an honor to speak to them about Spain, Venezuela, and the US. Finally, my son absolutely loved her chocolate cake, and she made sure that he got an extra big piece. It is an experience like this that makes visiting a foreign country such a true delight!

review_preview: My last meal before I left madrid and what a nice way to end. Arrived at the casino and was escorted up the old traditional elevator (where you have to open your own door) to the 3rd floor. The restaurant looks totally different from the...
review_full: My last meal before I left madrid and what a nice way to end. Arrived at the casino and was escorted up the old traditional elevator (where you have to open your own door) to the 3rd floor. The restaurant looks totally different from the casino lobby, which was in deep reds and browns and looking old. The restaurant being on the terrace, is bright and airy and dressed in white. Like a greenhouse They have 2 lunch sets and also a la carte option. I went with the shorter set, which already has about 8 courses I won't go into detail of each, but they were creative and outstanding . Liquid nitrogen, food hanging on a clothes peg, lots of molecular gastronomy techniques . They all aim to wow and succeeded. Perhaps the only disappointment was that my beef was undercooked  Even the tea selection was mind boggling . A large chest was rolled over and 2 drawers of about 100 blends appeared . Wow Service was great too Give them another star

The decor is very very grand, and the service is pretty formal, which we really enjoyed, whilst this may not be for everyone, the food overall was some of the very best I've eaten. Perfect for a more formal special occasion.

review_preview: For want of being a sour note in the otherwise glowing reports of this restaurant - please read the following and take care.  The building is indeed marvellous - the hall from which you take a lift to the restaurant is a marvel of Rococco...
review_full: For want of being a sour note in the otherwise glowing reports of this restaurant - please read the following and take care. The building is indeed marvellous - the hall from which you take a lift to the restaurant is a marvel of Rococco splendour with the most fabulous staircase. Sadly this is where the aesthetics came to a halt. We were guided to our seats in what felt like a corridor. The black and white floor, hideous grey pillars and mirrors felt like some set from a 70's film. Silence reigned with more waiters than there were clients. At this point we thought about making a run for it but the whole mechanism had already swung in to action. The menu degustation was akin to a bush tucker trial - some good parts, some simply awful and mostly completely ridiculous. We didn't know whether to laugh or cry. By the end of the evening even the waiters had begun to find the whole thing funny. As the menu ticked on we became more and more desperate for the experience to be over and actually began to feel really quite ill. The chef was skilled in a Heston Blumenthal fashion but sadly without the sense of humour. More was the complete lack of consideration of the layering of a menu and how eggs, chocolate clad fois gras, eel, pork etc etc might lie on a poor tummy. We were polaxed. It will stay for a long while as a memory and in time will be a marvellous addition to the family horror stories but right now it will go down as the worst supper my husband and I have ever had the misfortune to experience.

review_preview: I went to this restaurant with my wife for our anniversary. We often go to Michelin star restaurants so I will use those as my point of reference. I have to say, knowing that the chef behind El Bulli was a consultant here made us...
review_full: I went to this restaurant with my wife for our anniversary. We often go to Michelin star restaurants so I will use those as my point of reference. I have to say, knowing that the chef behind El Bulli was a consultant here made us walk in with high expectations...and except for some glitches with the wine this was a perfect meal. One quick logistical point - as in many 2 or 3 star restaurants you are expected to wear a jacket. if you dont bring one they will provide you with one (but always better to bring your own). So lets get into it: The place The restaurant is located on the roof of the casino (although I didn't see any casino). The building is a majestic building that must have a couple centuries in what I would call a French style. After a brief elevator ride you arrive at the last floor in a beautiful decor (they have an indoor option but we ate outside in the terrace). There was some live music (although I have to say a long tail piano would have been more appropriate than an electric organ but it was all good...) The food One comes to this sort of restaurant for the food and I have to say that for the food itself I would not have been surprised if this place had three stars. The 135 euro menu with some 20 courses was amazing. The dishes were innovative, inventive and surprising. It was a journey of culinary discovery...truly amazing. Don't come here if you are looking for large dishes with a home made feel...this is a place where food is an art...and at 135 euros for a 20 course menu it was a bargain. (You can also order "a la carte" but it may cost you just as much for less dishes). I've been to places that charge 2-3 times that and are not as interesting. I particularly enjoyed the "pasta bolognesa" (which actually is made of calamari) or the sole meunière which was amazing. The other 18 courses were also great and in the end you don't feel too full despite the number of dishes... The wine This was, in my humble opinion, what made this a 2 and not a 3 star restaurant. Given that my pregnant wife could not drink I asked the sommelier to match the dinner with wines by the glass...she quickly agreed but instead of making me experiment different wines as the courses came, she just left me a bottle of a very uninteresting Sauvignon blanc from Rueda (until I asked them to change - this was followed by an average Rioja). Yes, at 14 euros for the many glasses I had this was an amazing bargain...but I would expect a little more effort from this sort of restaurant. I overheard her explain to another table that the current menu was adapted to "white wines"...but a real effort would have been to make me discover 3-4 white wines...this was a disappointment. The wine menu seemed to be reasonable (a large book that I didn't go through) but this sort of restaurant should have the option to offer wines to match the multiple dishes offered (which is hard to do yourself unless you are in a group of 4+) The service This is what I would describe as the perfect service (aside from the wine episode). The service was attentive, non-intrusive and always present. I have food allergies and my wife has a ton of limitations as she is pregnant and they made multiple changes in the many courses without even the slightest pushback. Aside from that the service was quick but not pushy. Just as a notice, this is great European service...so don't expect the waiter to tell you his name or his favorite vacation spot...that would not be considered good service in this part of the world...don't take that as a signal of lack of interest or being pretentious...it's just the way things are (I am saying this because I read some of the comments that spoke of this) Overall I've been to most of the 2 star restaurants in Madrid and several one stars and feel comfortable saying that this is the best restaurant in town (I might change my mind but so far...). This is also one of the best restaurants I've been to in a while...probably just a notch below the Fat Duck (which we recently visited) or the Mugaritz (based on the experience as I would say the food itself is at least as good). Highly recommended!!! Don't miss this restaurant if you are really into innovative cuisine or are just open to taste things that are above the ordinary...

title_review: Not Your Best Bet in Madrid
review_preview: We opted to splurge one night while in Madrid and many of the guide books and this site recommended La Terraza as an experience to enjoy. While we are not fans of Michelin type restaurants, we gave it a roll. First and foremost, La Terraza...
review_full: We opted to splurge one night while in Madrid and many of the guide books and this site recommended La Terraza as an experience to enjoy. While we are not fans of Michelin type restaurants, we gave it a roll.  First and foremost, La Terraza is a private club and for some reason they open the restaurant to guests. The restaurant doesn't open until 9PM but in the off chance they were to open earlier, we arrived around 8:30PM and went to the bar. The bar is large and overly bright. We were the only ones inside on a Saturday night. Nothing was cozy or comfortable and we had to wait until 9PM for dinner.  Men must wear sport coats so I had to use one of the "in-house"coats to enter the restaurant. You are shuttled into the elevator where you are greeted by the house staff and then directed to your table. They know you are a guest but overall service is impeccable. The issue we had was the food itself. There is a tasting menu for $115Euro and ala carte. We selected ala carte. Being a Michelin two star restaurant, we were treated to many starters, each very small. Their pizza is actually a thin wafer covered in even thinner tuna. Fois gras was in a round biscuit. A single prawn still had its tail and feelers intact. If you enjoy fine dining with unusual food, then you will enjoy La Terraza.  But for us, the best options were the wine (nice selection) and complimentary chocolates at the end of the meal. Oh, getting on the elevator and walking out too.

I was here on a business dinner and would not return here for a personal visit. However it was a different experience. The restaurant is visually lovely but the atmosphere is funereal. The other diners from what we could hear of their conversations - it was very quiet - were also Americans. We saw only one Spanish speaking couple that evening. The waiters are courteous but take it all a bit too seriously for me. They missed our first course of the tasting menu and when I pointed it out, they didnt rectify that which was disappointing given how much our dinner cost. Overall it was a bit too stuffy and pretentious for my liking and I am used to eating at fine dining establishments. Food was tasty - but I wouldnt crave any single dish that I ate.

review_preview: What an experience it was! At first I (coming from the world of theatre myself) was scandalized going to a restaurant calling itself dstage. What would that eating hole with surely trendy but quite chubby decore have in common with the real stage???But it...
review_full: What an experience it was!  At first I (coming from the world of theatre myself) was scandalized going to a restaurant calling itself dstage. What would that eating hole with surely trendy but quite chubby decore have in common with the real stage??? But it turned out that it was truly the stage where the chabiness of the place was just a staging where the the atmosphere is set for you to abandon the preconceived and the snobiness of an expensive dining experience. Where every bite would make you feel alive, bring back memories and surprise you with discoveries, sometimes of unknown, or sometimes of combinations of the known tastes, like the final garlic chocolate desert. Who would of thought that garlic, the most despised of all the spices could be a queen and a final point d'orgue in a fabulous and estátic 16 course dining experience with paired white, red, sweet wines, sake, cider and even homemade gingerbeer??? In the end I feel grateful for my life, the company of people that are next to me(such as Edu, who made it possible) , the talent of Chef Diego Guerrero, someone who was crowned by Michelin stars, yet still humble and charming talking to his customers. And really baffled that a dining experience could give you such emotions.  It was an unic experience that I recommend to everyone.

review_full: We came back for another visit after last year when they first opened. Now they got the first star, the place was packed, Yet the service was still excellent. Diego's partner runs a smooth operation from beginning to end. His dishes explored a lot of ingredients, flavor and fragrance from the East and South America. It is moving more away from his traditional Basque cooking. There are some great dishes and a few misses. The place is still hard to fine even with Google Map (no sign or number). Best bet is to look for TRATTORIA PULCINELLA which is directly across the street.

title_review: Best meal of my whole life (and I have eaten all over the world!)
review_preview: We tend to eat out in the very best places as a treat or go out for breakfast! We came for dinner for a treat and it was an amazing treat. We had the Degustation Menu consisting of 22 separate courses/items! Everything was sublime. Every...
review_full: We tend to eat out in the very best places as a treat or go out for breakfast! We came for dinner for a treat and it was an amazing treat. We had the Degustation Menu consisting of 22 separate courses/items! Everything was sublime. Every mouthful was a delight. Best meal of my life so far! The environment is stunning. You arrive to a palace with chandeliers and gold leaf and we ate on the roof terrace under the stars. We had great fun watching the other diners and the food arriving at the other tables as part of a sequence and a dance, added to the experience.  Hard to pick just a few courses to comment on but the Iberian Pork with yucca and dates and the Tomato Rock along with the Vegetable Garden were standouts.  The biggest challenge for us early birders was arriving for dinner at 10pm and leaving just after 2am. Do not come if you cannot cope with the late and long dinner! Although I say it is worth going into training so you can stay the distance and enjoy every moment. Do not forget your jacket (tie not required) and do not attempt to take said jacket off! I do not recommend going on a food tour on the same day either! The giraffe in the photos, Mr D Raft, eats out a lot and this was his favourite ever too!

title_review: One of the very best in Madrid
review_preview: La Terraza del Casino is simply outstanding. We ordered a la carte for dinner and were provided 5 "snacks" that were profoundly delicious, clever and perfectly sequenced. The two starters ("Tomato Rock"--deconstructed Gazpacho- and the "Olive Oil Paella"--lobster, chicken and veggies with crunchy saffron rice)...
review_full: La Terraza del Casino is simply outstanding. We ordered a la carte for dinner and were provided 5 "snacks" that were profoundly delicious, clever and perfectly sequenced. The two starters ("Tomato Rock"--deconstructed Gazpacho- and the "Olive Oil Paella"--lobster, chicken and veggies with crunchy saffron rice) were as good as any we've ever tasted. The entrees -- Sole Meunière and an entrecôte with filled tomatoes--were excellent. We were totally full at this point but persevered to share the "Chocolate Root" dessert---a free form of three different types of chocolate in various formats over homemade lemon ice cream. Wow. Then, a two tiered box of chocolate truffles appeared! Service could not have been more accommodating and appropriate.  Make the effort to go. You won't be disappointed.

review_preview: Located in a fun neighborhood that certainly merits exploring, DSTAGE is an outwardly unassuming restaurant.  To our shocked surprise, alas, the visit started off on the wrong foot.  When we arrived, we were told our reservation did not exist.  We had made it through American...
review_full: Located in a fun neighborhood that certainly merits exploring, DSTAGE is an outwardly unassuming restaurant. To our shocked surprise, alas, the visit started off on the wrong foot. When we arrived, we were told our reservation did not exist. We had made it through American Express and it was confirmed by our hotel. We were not at all happy as this was one of a series of special dinners we had planned months in advance. Then we were told it was made for the day before our visit. Still extremely unhappy, we refused to budge so easily. After some back and forth and ruffling of feathers, they agreed to sit us at a small “overflow” table set up against a wall. Obviously, it was not ideal, but sometimes life ends up being one big compromise. Needless to say, after what we had gone through, I was prepared to be highly critical of the unfolding dining experience. Once the dust had settled, the staff was very gracious and we settled for the mid-sized dining option. The restaurant’s environs have a chic, industrial feel that is buttressed by a well-curated playlist of memorable American tunes. After finally settling in, to our pleasant surprise, the food turned out to be quite fabulous. After an appetizer of razor clams and champagne, we were taken back to the open kitchen and looked on as a young chef prepared us a complex appetizer of exceptional flavors. Overall, the food comprised a variety of exquisite flavor and texture combinations for which only pictures do ample justice (see photos). The courses were beautiful, unusual, and delicious and I could not find fault with any of them. The wine list offers many reasonably priced choices with a Spanish bent (the Sketch Albarino we had was sensationally pure). At the close of the meal, Mr. D, the chef-proprietor came to our table to thank us. Though, the dance started off with us stepping on each other’s toes, it fortunately transformed into a blissful waltz. I highly recommend the DSTAGE dining experience and I highly recommend double and triple confirming your reservation prior to arrival.
