review_preview: This restaurant deserves its two Michelin stars. The food is expertly prepared and very creative. The wine list is very extensive, with deep verticals of great Spanish wines, as well as reasonable prices for very good Spanish wines. But, because the service is outdoors, on...
review_full: This restaurant deserves its two Michelin stars. The food is expertly prepared and very creative. The wine list is very extensive, with deep verticals of great Spanish wines, as well as reasonable prices for very good Spanish wines. But, because the service is outdoors, on a terrace (at least in good weather) patrons are allowed to smoke, and smoke they do. When we became aware of this problem we complained to kurt server, and then to the maitre 'd. They blew its off, noting that we were in the minority. Tables were empty and set inside, but they refused to seat us there, perhaps because no one else was dining inside. Despite the outstanding food and wine, I cannot recommend this restaurant to a non-smoker, so long as seating is on the terrace.

title_review: Not ElBulli or ferran Adria  but an excellent meal
review_preview: Spectacular setting with a lobby reminiscent of a Newport mansion. Restaurant in elegant setting on upper floor of the casino de Madrid (a private club). Jacket required. A disciple of ferran Adria is head chief. Innovative 20+ mini-course tasting menu that began with a deconstructed...
review_full: Spectacular setting with a lobby reminiscent of a Newport mansion. Restaurant in elegant setting on upper floor of the casino de Madrid (a private club). Jacket required. A disciple of ferran Adria is head chief. Innovative 20+ mini-course tasting menu that began with a deconstructed "Bloody Mary" and had 8 starter courses then 8 tapiplatos! (And several sweet desert courses to finish) My favorite starter was surprisingly a "peanut" with a dab of spicy sauce, loved the fried quail egg too. A red mullet was great as a tapiplato as was a cabonara egg nest and a castanuelas plate. Wine list is 50 pages! We did a fino panesa sherry with early courses then a 2006 dominio de valdepusa followed by niepoort tawny port with the deserts (going local on the wines). Service excellent. I think several courses were great but several just ok as well. Club Allard in Madrid was better and this isn't 11 Madison park (NYC) by any stretch

I have always wanted to try Ferran Adria's food, so this was the closest thing for me in Madrid. The cocktail was crazy - they bring out a cart and make it in front of you, using dry ice - coffee, cherries...etc (I can't remember the exact ingredients) but it was so flavorful. Paco Roncero does amazing work. Each plate could easily be hung in a museum. It was an expensive lunch, but once you have it you can understand why. This experience in the states would have cost double though. It was a $200 lunch for the two of us with 10 courses that are plentiful and includes the cocktail. We also got 2 glasses of wine which was included in the $200 price. It was a great last lunch in Madrid for my boyfriend and I. //Staff was super too//

We enjoyed the Taster Menu with 8 starters and 8 main courses followed by a selection of desserts whilst serenaded by a flautist and pianist. Our personal waiter explained the ingredients in each course - some of which were absolutely mind blowing; the occasion was very special and this was not lost on the staff who presented my sister and I with a cake and candles and complimentary champagne at the end of the evening. I loved the whole night and would recommend La Terraza to anyone who wants to treat themselves to a true culinary experience - many thanks to all of the staff who contributed to the evening's success.

review_full: The good Trip Advisor reviews prompted us to go here - they were well deserved. It was our first night in Madrid and we didn't quite understand the knack of ordering tapas and ended up ordering far too much - all delicious, so it wasn't that much of a problem! Another customer helped us and the bar tender with our wine selection and it was a gorgeous rioja - beautifully rounded and with a lovely flavour. Result! With our subsequent experience with tapas, I would say the tapas here has been taken to a new level - it was not the 'traditional' fare offered elsewhere. For instance we had black pudding dumpling and pork cheeks; not things we saw in other tapas bars. It would be a problem to get in at busy times I guess; we sat in the small bar area as you go in and there was a very small seating area downstairs. Highly recommended.

It’s a bunch of small tables with stools and bench seating. The wallpaper is filled with old US news papers. There’s a cluster of other odd and ends garage sale like items all over. Aside from that, the food was very good and service was excellent. The tapas are unlike those you find in the other typical restaurants. Go for the tapas and be open minded to the food there. It is delicious.

title_review: Taking my celiac cousin out for tapas
review_preview: We tried to call the restaurant to book, but nobody picked up. When we arrived at 20.00 fortunately there was a free table. The taberna is quite small, in a basement, but the food made up for it. It had the celiac version of all...
review_full: We tried to call the restaurant to book, but nobody picked up. When we arrived at 20.00 fortunately there was a free table. The taberna is quite small, in a basement, but the food made up for it. It had the celiac version of all the tapas on the menu. Even if we found the tapas a little on the expensive side, all of them were really tasty! We tried the lentils with caramelized duck and foie, the bacalao toast, the cabrelas and anchovies toast (very strong) and the fish balls in thai curry (which was reallyyyy good!). Please note that the toasts come in 2 per portion, so for two persons 1 portion should be enough to try. We were full by the time the excellent fish balls came, and the lady said they could not pack the remaining food as take-out, which was a shame!

review_full: Just came back from our tapas run and chose this Taverna because of the TA reviews. We walked in and at first we were a tad shocked by the size. But the charming owner/ waitress assured us there was room for us down the stairs. Sure enough, she cleared a table for four pronto! The boys had beer and the girls had red wine. We ordered: tomatoes and mozzarella stack, meatballs, cheese platter and some cold tomatoes puréed . Everything was delicious. Plenty to share and the waitress just kept running up and down the stairs for whatever we asked for ( we went thru 4 baskets of bread it was that good). You won't go wrong here for sure!!

The place is a tourist trap, with some dishes good and others bad, but for sure is not an “authentic spanish tapas”place. But the most horrible thing was the service downstairs. We were still eating when the waitress asked us to leave. And when we asked why she’s asking customers to leave while they’re still eating, the only reason is because they have reservation on that table for the next hour. We challenged this system and asked that we at least want to order dessert and this waitress suddenly grabbed our unfinished plates angrily and said in a high voice, “fine then tell me what you want!” She herself had caused the disturbance in that small room downstairs. I don’t usually leave reviews but I feel compelled to do so this time just to share this experience.

review_preview: Was very happy to come here and try out Diego's place.  The food was exactly as I expected, fun and tasty.  I don't know whether they have two seatings a night, but all I can say is it was crazy to serve my 14 course...
review_full: Was very happy to come here and try out Diego's place. The food was exactly as I expected, fun and tasty. I don't know whether they have two seatings a night, but all I can say is it was crazy to serve my 14 course meal paired with wine in one hour 45 minutes. ( 7 1/2 min per course, between 9pm to 10:45 pm ) , no wonder I have indigestion now as I am writing this. I have been to Noma three times and el celler de can roca once in the past two years, I understand Diego is trying to democratize his food and not keep guests in his restaurant for too long (I don't like 4 hour meals either). Would suggest opening up 8:00/8:30 pm instead, then the meals can be more enjoyable !

title_review: Welcoming little place with great value, tasty food
review_preview: Four of us visited Taberna La Concha in late December for dinner. We made a booking, which did not turn out to be needed as we dined very early by Madrid/Spanish custom, sitting down just after 8pm.The welcome was warm, very friendly despite our...
review_full: Four of us visited Taberna La Concha in late December for dinner. We made a booking, which did not turn out to be needed as we dined very early by Madrid/Spanish custom, sitting down just after 8pm. The welcome was warm, very friendly despite our lack of Spanish. The staff we meet bent over backwards to assist us and were in all respects delightful hosts. We dined on a great selection of tapas dishes, each of which was enjoyable and well presented. The wine ( a DOC Rioja) was excellent value indeed. Décor downstairs is basic but we enjoyed the absence of pretense, the focus clearly being upon food and wine.  Cost was ridiculously low for the amount and quality of food we had, so I am very happy to recommend Lac Concha to fellow travelers.

review_preview: I'd tried to go here before, and it was too busy to get in, which shows how popular it is. I went as soon as it opened at lunchtime, so we had our pick of tables (we chose downstairs where it is cosy and a...
review_full: I'd tried to go here before, and it was too busy to get in, which shows how popular it is. I went as soon as it opened at lunchtime, so we had our pick of tables (we chose downstairs where it is cosy and a bit more private). They have an amazing selection of tapas dishes, including a whole gluten free menu. Being a coeliac, this was very exciting for me! They brought us a free appetizer with our drinks, as well as a sweet bite for pudding after we'd eaten. We went for 4 dishes between two of us, and they were generous sizes! They also came with gluten free bread, and it was the same price for GF as for 'normal' tapas. The service was fab and I thoroughly enjoyed the dining experience, as well as the yummy GF food!

review_preview: We were out for a "paseo"  in Madrid on a Saturday night and decided to try this casual place on one of the main pedestrian streets in Madrid.  The food was very good, the selection reasonably long and quite creative and inexpensive.  We had goat...
review_full: We were out for a "paseo" in Madrid on a Saturday night and decided to try this casual place on one of the main pedestrian streets in Madrid. The food was very good, the selection reasonably long and quite creative and inexpensive. We had goat cheese croquettes, a lovely toast with pork, cheese and carmelized onions and a Spanish omelette. We couldn't finish it all ( although we had already had some Tapas at another restaurant). With 2 glasses of wine the bill came to 21 euros. The staff was enthusiastic and very responsive. This is not fine dining but the place has a nice casual feel to it and they really do aim to please. Highly recommended.!

title_review: Great food and staff, celiac / gluten free no problem
review_preview: This is a great place, extremely good value for the money. The staff spoke excellent English and were very nice. The bar upstairs is small, and downstairs there is seating for about 20 people. It is not super fancy, but has great, traditional home style...
review_full: This is a great place, extremely good value for the money. The staff spoke excellent English and were very nice. The bar upstairs is small, and downstairs there is seating for about 20 people. It is not super fancy, but has great, traditional home style tapas and genuinely friendly service. For those of us who need it, most pf the menu is gluten free, and they will bring gluten free bread. As a celiac / coeliac, I particularly appreciated the fact that they understood how to prepare food so it is truly gluten free, and suitable for celiacs. We went there twice and really enjoyed it. A reservation is probably a good idea as the place is small.

You don't say this enterieur is beautiful. It has trendy, young design, but don't take your wife for an anniversary dinner :) White wine they offered was the best we had in Madrid, very nice, fresh. Checking the menu, we saw they don't have the typical tapas, what you can see at most places. And that was we're looking for! I'm sorry, others chose foie gras etc, why? We thought it is better to go for local. We really liked the pimiento with local cheese stuffing, that was brilliant. We went there a few days later again, to have that meal! The lentil with duck was also great, as well the fish balls with green curry. Next time - because we went back - we had prawn toast, which was OK, but not so brilliant as the other tapas.

title_review: Food was just average, won't be coming back
review_preview: We went here for dinner and ordered three tapas: Atillo de morcilla (blood sausage), foie gras mi cuit and duck orange. They have menus in many languages, which is nice, and the waitress was very nice too, if a bit slow, which is normal in...
review_full: We went here for dinner and ordered three tapas: Atillo de morcilla (blood sausage), foie gras mi cuit and duck orange. They have menus in many languages, which is nice, and the waitress was very nice too, if a bit slow, which is normal in Spain. We seated downstairs and there was no-one else around. The décor is all right, but there were lots of flies swarming the lights in the ceiling. The morcilla arrived first, and it was fantastic, absolutely loved it. The two next tapas were more expensive, and worse too! The foie gras is exactly the same kind that you can buy at Mercadona (Martiko brand), but at a much higher price, and the bread was thin and tasteless, although I suppose that's so you can enjoy the foie gras flavour. The orange duck came with real orange, but again was nothing special. We had two glasses of wine, and the red wine was cold, which we didn't like. The price was probably what you'd expect in the centre of town (i.e. too expensive), but the quality of the food did not match it.

The amount of food was compared to the price very small. The croquetas were not to bad though. We have ordered the hummus, which did not taste like hummus at all and all of us have eaten hummus several times in different locations before. After complaining we were offered an other hummus, which tasted the same.  We did not have to pay for the hummus in the end, but in conclusion with the slow service, we would not recommend this bar.  Wondering why the reviews on TripAdvisor are so good we had a flick through. Noticing that a lot of 5 star reviews were made by people who only reviewed this place and no other bars since registered.

review_preview: In sharp contrast with The Ledbury in London, this Michelin-starred restaurant deserves nothing but praise! It is absolutely top-notch, in terms of innovation, attention to detail, service, and quality of food of course!Pictures to follow - Food: exquisite and takes you on a truly...
review_full: In sharp contrast with The Ledbury in London, this Michelin-starred restaurant deserves nothing but praise! It is absolutely top-notch, in terms of innovation, attention to detail, service, and quality of food of course! Pictures to follow -  Food: exquisite and takes you on a truly globe-trotting fantasy Dstage took our breath away upon arrival, with TWO amazing amuse bouche dishes. The first is a nitrogen/halogen bed of crustaceans carpaccio dish framed in a wooden box, the second is when we were whisked away to the open bar, where an inviting performance of putting together the red prawn ceviche on a block of volcanic salt awaits. Exquisiteeee Several really good dishes followed, inspired by Thai and Japanese influences but utilizing the best and seasonal Spanish produce. The most wonderful thing was that wherever possible, the Dstage attendant would whisk up the dish in front of your eyes, garnished and amazingly fresh!  The main that caught us off guard was the smoked hanger steak, with the charcoal still smoking the most tender meat inside a wooden box. AMAZING - it reminded us a twinge of our Chinese "cha siu" (barbequed pork, yummm).  The desserts were great, the last dish looked so much like a garlic that we almost expected the meringue to taste garlicky! All in all, an absolute treat - deserves TWO stars at the very least. Wine also wonderful! Service: almost impeccable, treats you like personal friends Perhaps it's the personal touch that made us felt so well taken care of, in any case the service was great. Just took a tad long to fetch us our bill in the end - just a speck really. Ambience - a bit casual but cozy and lovely On the exterior, they maintain a very understated and dark impression, a shop front which could easily be overlooked. No signs or indications of the luxurious foodie experience that lies within. Interior design wise, it's probably meant to be cozy, furnished with wood, has a small courtyard visible from the downstairs washroom. All in all a very comfortable place and friendly ambience. MUST GO!

title_review: Two fantastic meals in three days!
review_preview: My husband and I visited La Concha one evening and returned two nights later, simply because the food is fantastic, the staff were very pleasant and their Vermouth is great! The atmosphere was very comfortable, this is what we felt was lacking in other restaurants...
review_full: My husband and I visited La Concha one evening and returned two nights later, simply because the food is fantastic, the staff were very pleasant and their Vermouth is great!  The atmosphere was very comfortable, this is what we felt was lacking in other restaurants we ate in. We returned to La Concha as we enjoyed our first meal so much and knew if we returned we were almost guaranteed another enjoyable meal. During our stay in Madrid, we were a bit disappointed (at other restaurants) with the variety of food, taste and service.  We wouldn't hesitate in recommending this restaurant - it's a must visit when in Madrid!

review_preview: We ate twice here during our weeklong stay in Madrid. It was the only eating place we could find in our internet trawls that  advertised itself as providing gluten free food, apart from a bakery which we did not get round to visiting. We were...
review_full: We ate twice here during our weeklong stay in Madrid. It was the only eating place we could find in our internet trawls that advertised itself as providing gluten free food, apart from a bakery which we did not get round to visiting. We were able to get gluten free food elsewhere, with the help of preprinted cards in Spanish explaining our need, but in Taberna la Concha it was very reassuring to have a special gluten free menu available, along with gluten free bread. When you look into the front door it appears to be a very small bar with only about a half a dozen seats and patrons, however there is a seating area downstairs which is well serviced by a lady who was there both times, servicing the diners singlehandedly and jogging up and down the stairs to get the food and drinks. We tried about 7 of their tapas dishes on the 2 separate occasions we were there, sharing them between us. The food is rustic and tasty. We tasted their cava, a number of sherries and other wine. Recommended for a simple, light, healthy gluten free meal which can be had slightly earlier in the evening than the usual Spanish dining hours of after 8 or 8.30 pm

title_review: Wonderful way to end our stay in Madrid..
review_preview: Came here solely on the recommendations of Trip Advisor and wasn't disappointed! We had initially tried to visit on a Friday night, but they were fully booked all evening (not surprising, given the downstairs area only seats about 12 people)Tried again about 7.30pm on...
review_full: Came here solely on the recommendations of Trip Advisor and wasn't disappointed!  We had initially tried to visit on a Friday night, but they were fully booked all evening (not surprising, given the downstairs area only seats about 12 people) Tried again about 7.30pm on Sunday and we were the only ones there for the most part of our meal. The lady serving spoke good English - always a help as we speak no Spanish apart from the very basic. Not being very adventurous (and not seafood/fish lovers) we chose 5 dishes to share - meatballs (amazing, a favourite), cured saltbeef (pleasant), cheese-stuffed peppers (INCREDIBLE), pork cheeks (tender and tummy) and a cheese plate (excellent, but then we adore cheese!).  We were very kindly bought a free goats cheese tapas starter and strawberries for dessert, as well as 2 free baskets of bread, and the whole thing was a wonderful experience!

title_review: Made our first night in Madrid, outstanding.

review_full: If you're not careful you could walk right by the place. Once my daughter and I entered we went down the stairs and immediately felt like we were eating in a couple's house cellar. Once seated we received the Tapa of the day, and ordered wine.  This was my first experience with Tapas, but not my daughter's since she studies in Spain, and even she said it was her favorite experience thus far. We ordered three tapas for the two of us, ate the tapa of the day, and received complimentary dessert tapas (strawberry with whipped cream and chocolate drizzle) and could not have been more pleased. Definitely worth the money.  Go! You will not regret it.  Ps. Get the cheese stuffed red peppers. You're welcome.

Needless to say I did not eat any of it and they still charged me! I would have had a better meal at Burger King just down the road. If you are not bothered what you eat then this is the place for you. If you are, then would suggest you give this place a miss.

Walked to the address and the first surprise: there was no sign outside with the name, not the usual stickers of accepted credit cards, e.g. The next surprise: the restaurant was almost fully booked and we got the last free table. The biggest surprise: exceptional and delicious food. The restaurant offers only 2 menus, one with 10 and the other with 15 courses(!). We decided to take the small one but it was really more than enough. It started at the bar with the first course, the second course was prepared and served at the kitchen, all other than served at the table. Each course described whats inside and even how to eat it. The food was a kind of molecular gastronomy but not to much or to weird.

review_preview: I am often wary of best rated restaurants on Tripadvisor, but this time everybody got it right.  My husband and I had a fabulous experience at DStage last night, and I can't imagine anything could have made it better.  The food was innovative, utterly delicious,...
review_full: I am often wary of best rated restaurants on Tripadvisor, but this time everybody got it right. My husband and I had a fabulous experience at DStage last night, and I can't imagine anything could have made it better. The food was innovative, utterly delicious, but it was the overall experience that put it over the top. Our very well developed palates were challenged and stimulated and we learned a lot about different flavor combinations. This place is young and hip and where it's happening, yet respectful of diners of every age and nationality. What a creative team, from the chef and kitchen staff to the sommelier to the wait staff. The setting, too, is laid back and relaxed, in a former beer shop. Both casual and classy! We have eaten in many fine restaurants all over the world, and this experience stands with the top 10. Did I mention that we loved it?

review_preview: We have been travelling for 3 weeks now and been to six Michelin star restaurants.  DSTAgE is easily the best and in my view it is worthy of more than one Michelin star.  Diego Guerrero is not only an innovative and highly skilled chef, he...
review_full: We have been travelling for 3 weeks now and been to six Michelin star restaurants. DSTAgE is easily the best and in my view it is worthy of more than one Michelin star. Diego Guerrero is not only an innovative and highly skilled chef, he also understands that good restaurants should be about more than providing good food and wine - they should provide a performance to enhance the experience. At DSTAgE, you are introduced into the restaurant by starting in the bar with a drink and a very theatrical serving of razor clams. Then onto the kitchen bench where a chef prepares another course as you watch. Then to the table where you can watch the open kitchen at work. Finishing touches are made to a couple of the dishes at the table and the wait staff provide informative, though not pretentious or patronising, explanations of each dish - in very good English for those of us with poor Spanish. The rooms themselves are a skilled combination of casual, stylish and elegant. I also loved the soundtrack, a great combination of old classic hits that subtly reminded everyone that we are here to have fun and not take ourselves too seriously. The food itself is sublime. Wonderful, sometimes quirky and unexpected combinations of ingredients, flavours and textures. Who would think of corn flavoured ice cream wrapped in a taco made of fairy floss?! Great theatre, delicious to eat. There is an extensive wine list and we were given very good advice on a wine to suit the food and our tastes. Also very reasonably priced. If you are in Madrid, or even within 100kms, and are at all interested in great restaurant experiences, then you really should visit DSTAgE.

You have the option of a 10 course or 14 course menu. We selected 10 courses that was ample for lunch and then enjoyed 150 minutes of delicious food and the theatre of at table final preparation plus a full description of ingredients and techniques used. Try for a table in the back room near the open kitchen so you can appreciate the full production. Chef Diego Guerrero both cooks and conducts this wonderful meal. This restaurant well deserves its Michelin Star and is well worth the cost.

review_full: Made the booking three months in advance and wasn't disappointed. The food is creative and fun as you'd expect of a newly-opened Michelin-starred restaurant in a hip neighborhood. Staff were very knowledgeable about wine and the details about specific ingredients. The head chef and owner is a nice man who performed a demonstration of one of the courses to us personally, which was a cool way to interact with customers rather than the usual interaction with head chefs which centers around "how did you like the food? please come again." Atmosphere is relaxed and informal with five star food and service. They told us that the menu is always customized for each customer so if you were to return within a short period of time you would be presented with a whole new set of tasting delight.

review_preview: My spouse and I found ourselves repeatedly returning here (5 times) during our trip to Madrid (mid June to mid July) and only dinner commitments at our many relatives in Madrid kept us from returning even more.It's easy to get to the H10 bar from...
review_full: My spouse and I found ourselves repeatedly returning here (5 times) during our trip to Madrid (mid June to mid July) and only dinner commitments at our many relatives in Madrid kept us from returning even more.It's easy to get to the H10 bar from the Anton Martin Metro Station (a 2-3 block walk through an eclectic, interesting neighborhood). On hot summer afternoons we supplemented the good air conditioning with large pitchers of marvelous fruit-filled sangria that was way too good to describe adequately. On evening visits we'd have a very good albarino (18 euros per bottle) or one of various tintos that were also very good and similarly priced. Various tapas were of moderate-large size and seemingly prepared with care from fresh quality ingredients (tostadas of Iberian pork and goat cheese, large mushrooms stuffed with ham and cheese, meat balls, …) and some tapas came with small salads on the plate as well. If you elect to be less sinful and avoid tasty tapas, then their simple Mediterranean salad would suit you. Paella in Spain can be wonderful or a mistake to order, but we were pleasantly surprised by their really good vegetable paella. On some visits we had great fun chatting with the waiters or with other guests at nearby tables (halfway through a pitcher of sangria or bottle of wine). Prices here are inexpensive to moderate (certainly great value for your money). The bill for the two of us (food, alcohol, and a good tip) was generally 40-45 euros and we'd leave full and somewhat tipsy. This bar may be great for you if you want to meet people and chat, visit with a small group of friends, have a romantic first date, or have a great time with your partner of 40 years. Honestly, however, it's not the tasty food and great drink that hooks you here. It's how welcome the staff make you feel. You're at ease, comfortable, and it's fun. All the waiters are helpful and cool people. I must say we both found our hostess, Delimer, warm, fun-loving, and just honestly human. My spouse is more receptive and open while I'm generally the skeptic. Delimer and the H10 bar have unequivocally become our friends!!!

review_full: Last Sunday, my friends (who came to see a concert) and I decided to go for a walk in the area of Huertas. It was about 2pm and a hot day so we stopped for a drink and some tapas at the H10-Bar. The location was perfect, at the beginning of la calle Huertas. The look of the food and its presentation was quite appealing, the service was quick and nice but the taste of the food was not up to expectations. We order magret de pato, arroz negro con langostinos, cazuela de langostinos, champiñones rellenos de queso y jamón y salmorejo. The duck wasn’t tender and it was cold. The rice with king prawns was plain. The small pot of king prawns too greasy. The mushrooms had a buttered bulletproof jacket...impossible to eat them. I took pics of the food so you can see what I mean. Definitely they have to improve the quality of the food. Service and presentation are good as I said before.

title_review: Delicious food, with a warm and welcoming vibe
review_preview: The goats cheese and iberian ham croquettes were absolutely delicious and very filling for such a reasonable price. The bar itself is softly lit, with great air con and music for cooling down after a stroll around the streets of Madrid. Staff are very friendly...
review_full: The goats cheese and iberian ham croquettes were absolutely delicious and very filling for such a reasonable price.  The bar itself is softly lit, with great air con and music for cooling down after a stroll around the streets of Madrid.  Staff are very friendly and tentative without being instrusive, with a great level of English which is helpful for the solo traveller who may not have a lot of Spanish.  The menu is varied, at a low cost with a lot of tapas options.  The caprihinia cocktails are icy and refreshing, with even a free after dinner shot of limoncello provides by Mike. Thank you very much for making my visit a very pleasant one!

I think you could try other Italian places in the neighbourhood and we could compare notes then.

review_preview: We visited Trattoria Malatesta twice on our recent visit to Madrid.  The first time we had to wait for a table as they were busy but it was well worth the wait.  The second time we booked to save messing about and were able to...
review_full: We visited Trattoria Malatesta twice on our recent visit to Madrid. The first time we had to wait for a table as they were busy but it was well worth the wait. The second time we booked to save messing about and were able to get to our table a few minutes early. Both times, service was excellent, friendly and attentive without being intrusive. Both times we shared a buffalo mozzarella, tomato and rocket salad which was spot on. My wife had Carbonara on both visits, having enjoyed it the first time. I had spaghetti with octopus on our first visit which was fantastic. Second time around I had ravioli con gamberi in a clam and courgette sauce, again, this was wonderful. We also shared a Ricotta and Pear cheesecake which was light as a feather and finished our meal really well. Both visits, with drinks, came to around 50 euros, which was very reasonable in the context of Madrid prices and was worth every penny. If you like Italian food, cooked and made fresh, this is the place to be.

title_review: Great customer service, food, drinks, and music
review_preview: First impressions:  The employees are very welcoming and quickly offered a table. The bathroom is clean and had lots of soap which is always something I pay attention to. The place is quite cozy with modern decorations and a cool vibe. The downstairs seating was...
review_full: First impressions:   The employees are very welcoming and quickly offered a table. The bathroom is clean and had lots of soap which is always something I pay attention to. The place is quite cozy with modern decorations and a cool vibe. The downstairs seating was great with romantic lighting perfect for me and my date. Music: The music was great and the waiter even asked if I had any request. So that was pretty cool!  Food:  The food was really tasty. I really enjoyed the chorizo and cheesy sweet pepper croquettes. The oreo chocolate croquette was amazing and loved how the chocolate melted inside my mouth. It was awesome! We ordered a lot of croquettes and glasses of wines and the service was fast! I felt like I was in croquette and wine heaven. The wine I loved the most matched perfectly with dessert it was sweet and just something I have never experienced before. I forget the name of the wine but just ask for a wine that goes with the cheesecake and oreo chocolate croquette they will know what you are talking about! I felt like a true Spaniard while I was here. I will totally come here again and recommend to all of my friends.

review_preview: We loved this place! We got there right at opening (which is 8pm!).  I would recommend getting here early since it filled up pretty quick-there are only a few tables in this little establishment.  It's located on a street with a lot of great tapas...
review_full: We loved this place! We got there right at opening (which is 8pm!). I would recommend getting here early since it filled up pretty quick-there are only a few tables in this little establishment. It's located on a street with a lot of great tapas bars actually. There was only one server so I'm glad we got there early so I could ask all my questions before he got so busy. I wish I had gotten his name because he was quite phenomenal! Food was outstanding, though a lot on the sweeter side which we aren't used to yet. We tried some tapas we never tried before: the blood sausage with onion which was surprisingly good (if you can get the idea of blood sausage out of your head, it's pretty good) and their chicken one. For 6 euros, you get 2 pieces per order which for two petite women filled us up quickly (largely due to the bread base). However, we ordered some more and thank gosh the waiter advised us to get 1/3 order of the calamari and half order of the duck foie (who would've thought fraction ordering was possible?). It would've been way too much food if we had gotten the full orders and this way, we got to try almost everything we wanted to try. Both the calamari with squid ink as well as the duck foie were quite tasty.  Highly recommend!!

review_preview: Casa Lucas is quite an informal restaurant with friendly, helpful staff and English menus available. There's a large bar and not many tables, so it feels more like a cafe, but the food is of a good restaurant standard. I fully endorse the recommendations for...
review_full: Casa Lucas is quite an informal restaurant with friendly, helpful staff and English menus available. There's a large bar and not many tables, so it feels more like a cafe, but the food is of a good restaurant standard. I fully endorse the recommendations for the oxtail, but the tuna and black pasta dishes were also much enjoyed. The risotto with foie would not be to everyone's taste. There is no dessert menu. Not being familiar with many Spanish wines, I asked the waiter for one with a fruity flavour, and his recommendation was excellent. We had two bottles between 5, which is partly why the bill came to 150 euros. So, it's not the cheapest meal you could have in Madrid, but it's likely to be one of the most enjoyable.

We waited for approximately 30 minutes while several other people were being seated so I went to the waiter again and showed the reservation to him, and actually had to get angry with him. He eventually came to our table and gave us menu's. The service got better after that, but I shouldn't have to get angry in order to be served. The food was ok but expensive. There are so many restaurants in Madrid. I would not recommend this place.

review_full: After reading so many good reviews, I had to try this place. We were not disappointed. The seats weren't the most comfortable, but I forgot about that immediately once the food and drink came out. Our waiter, Pablo, was very friendly and helpful. He gave wine recommendations and helped us determine just the right amount of food to order.  I felt I needed to try the Ox Tail since I was in Spain, though I worried that it would be fatty and/or have cartilage. However, it was amazing! No bones, no cartilage, just perfectly cooked, melt-in-your-mouth meat. The sauce it was on was like silky smooth mashed potatoes and was fantastic. My wife ordered the Cous Cous, which I don't think of as a traditional Spanish meal, but it also was amazing! We would definitely come back.

title_review: Should have been good but maybe we were unlucky
review_preview: We thought we were going to have the best seafood experience in Madrid here as it specialises in fish and seafood.  Maybe we were unlucky but that didn't turn out to be the case for us.  The tables are quite close together and the place...
review_full: We thought we were going to have the best seafood experience in Madrid here as it specialises in fish and seafood. Maybe we were unlucky but that didn't turn out to be the case for us. The tables are quite close together and the place was very busy but our waiter seemed anxious for us to hurry up and order. We wanted to take our time so ordered some wine and water and perused the menu. We asked the waiter for advice on the seafood paellas and he recommended the arroz a banda where the main seafood is cooked separately on a grill with a little bit of smaller bits cooked in the rice. The rice bit was good but the mixed seafood was way overcooked and dry. A real shame. We had shared some grilled vegetables to start and they were nice. The people at the table next to us had steak and pulpo - both looked good, so as I said, maybe we were just unfortunate. If we'd been staying longer in Madrd we might have given it another go as some of the food we saw did look better than ours.

title_review: Guess We Started Off On the Wrong Foot
review_preview: Wife wanted a certain dish so we went out of our way as this place was recommended for it. When we arrived I asked if they had that dish, I get an affirmative answer but a strange look back from one (a mix of surprise,...
review_full: Wife wanted a certain dish so we went out of our way as this place was recommended for it.  When we arrived I asked if they had that dish, I get an affirmative answer but a strange look back from one (a mix of surprise, slight annoyance mixed in with a dimwit expression). Call my wife in that the found the right place. The restaurant looks good, one family near the entrance and a couple at a two seater mid-restaurant. A larger party of two couples was leaving as we came in. Place is definitely not crowed but the dimwit waitress motions us to another two seater right next to the couple. Only seven customers in the restaurant but here we are sitting within inches of another couple.  I didn't let that bother me (then) but as we discuss our menu choices while the other couple sitting inches away from us try to continue their conversation we wait, and we wait, and we keep on waiting. The younger dimwit waitress is busy clearing off the table of the party that just left, no doubt rushing to clear off the one table as the other 25 or so empty tables would not do in case of a rush. The other waitress just kept sitting at the cash register. My wife is still reading the menu but I put my menu down.  Can't get eye contact from the waitress at the register. I could have spoken aloud but the curt manner in which we were directed to a table right next to another couple when many tables were free and the obvious lack of rush to ask us for drink orders convinced us that we must have started off on the wrong foot with those two.  We left and had a great dinner elsewhere. This looked like it would have been a good spot but once it starts going downhill with the waitstaff, no point in staying around to have an irritating experience.

title_review: Pretty restaurant with good rice dishes
review_preview: We initially went here on the recommendation of our hotel, but enjoyed it enough to return the following evening.It's a very attractive space, with interesting décor. It's also relatively easy to get a table, especially if you want to eat a bit earlier than...
review_full: We initially went here on the recommendation of our hotel, but enjoyed it enough to return the following evening. It's a very attractive space, with interesting décor. It's also relatively easy to get a table, especially if you want to eat a bit earlier than the average Madrileno! It's hard to see past the paellas. We sampled two - the mixed seafood and then the chicken/rabbit/artichoke etc one. I preferred the former and my husband the latter, which probably says they were both good. We shared a starter of mixed grilled veg on our first visit, which was excellent. Next time we shared a salad of spinach, smoked duck breast and sundried tomato. This was refreshing but had a very few tiny slivers of duck which made it a bit over-priced. We had a glass of wine each at first visit, and a bottle of the same enjoyable white next evening. Both meals came to a reasonable total, including bread and water etc, of between 65 and 69 euros. Service was brisk and efficient. A little friendlier on our first visit, and we got a complimentary liqueur then too. But overall we twice enjoyed a tasty meal in lovely surroundings.

review_preview: Service was excellent (welcoming and not stuffy) in this very interesting one-of-a-kind restaurant! They served us our first course, a wonderful concoction of razor clams, at the bar. The clams were atop a bed of seaweed and just melted in our mouths! They then served...
review_full: Service was excellent (welcoming and not stuffy) in this very interesting one-of-a-kind restaurant! They served us our first course, a wonderful concoction of razor clams, at the bar. The clams were atop a bed of seaweed and just melted in our mouths! They then served us our second course in the kitchen, with the chef preparing a modern and very delicious ceviche in front of us! We ate the rest of our meal in our table, where very enthusiastic and friendly servers, prepped food in front of us. Our family has eaten in several Michelin-star restaurants but our experience here stands out! The courses were innovative and delectable. I especially loved the simulated Peking duck dish, the exquisite octopus, and the cotton candy taco dessert. For those who want to eat here, definitely make a reservation as this is a restaurant that should not be missed!

review_preview: My companion and I ate here our last night in Madrid.  Great choice for a grand finale!  We arrived about 7:45, and there were only two other tables occupied, but by 8:30 there wasn't an empty seat.  Almost all were Spanish -this isn't slanted (or...
review_full: My companion and I ate here our last night in Madrid. Great choice for a grand finale! We arrived about 7:45, and there were only two other tables occupied, but by 8:30 there wasn't an empty seat. Almost all were Spanish -this isn't slanted (or priced) for tourists. The service and food were both terrific. Although almost everyone else was sharing paellas, we opted for the sea bass, which was perfectly prepared. For dessert a caramelized apple crunch (yummie!), all washed down with our favorite red, Habla del Silencio. I highly recommend this restaurant, and the next time I'm in Madrid I will definitely eat here again (and get a rice dish).

review_preview: It was our third visit to Dstage, and it continues to, in the end, leave you speechless and looking forward to another visit - albeit in a year from now!Trying the full tasting menu, this time with 8 associated wine choices, is an experience...
review_full: It was our third visit to Dstage, and it continues to, in the end, leave you speechless and looking forward to another visit - albeit in a year from now! Trying the full tasting menu, this time with 8 associated wine choices, is an experience best not spoiled by over-detailed reviewing. Start at the bar with a fresh seafood aperitif, before moving on to the kitchen pass for a handmade pre-starter cooked (potentially, if you're lucky, by Diego himself) on something you'd probably never thinking of heating up and using as a griddle. You then head to your table, where each course is explained in careful detail, with advice on how to best to actually eat many of the dishes whose appearance and contents often leave you wishing using Google in a restaurant was good form. This year, I should note Diego's been to Thailand and China, and the fusion of these flavours with the techniques and ideas picked up on some of his previous travels is simply astounding. You'll laugh at the combinations. You'll sit wide-eyed at the beauty of the presentation. You'll run out of adjectives before the end of the evening. As I said, almost no spoilers here about the food. It's better NOT to run through the masses of photos online. Go wanting to be surprised. But, if you want one tip, request the Raviolis de alubias. Unforgettable, authentic and amusing at the same time. The service is excellent, up to and including phoning to ask about allergies in advance. The decor and lighting is simple, unfussy and comfortable. The price is nothing short of a bargain compared to other restaurants in this class. As near as you'll get, probably, to affordable Michelin dining. If you get the chance, go.

review_preview: We came here to celebrate my father's 70th birthday, and it was worthy of the occasion. A set menu for about €85 per head ensured that we were well fed, with a detailed description of what we were going to eat presented by our waitress....
review_full: We came here to celebrate my father's 70th birthday, and it was worthy of the occasion. A set menu for about €85 per head ensured that we were well fed, with a detailed description of what we were going to eat presented by our waitress. A number of food allergies in the group meant that some "off-menu" options were required, but these were dealt with with minimum fuss, and the individual wasn't made to feel awkward (which some places can do). The only criticism - and it was probably for our own good in the end - was when we asked our waitress for a dessert wine, and she went to get the menu....and never came back because her shift ended! We just made do with finishing our very good albariño instead - but their loss in terms of revenue! The most memorable dish for me was the "reverse fabada" - a wonderful clear broth with little "beans" filled with the intense taste of ham stock, and pillows filled with a bean paste. Fabulous! If you like good, artistic food, go there.

review_preview: If you want to go on a culinary adventure in an unpretentious and cozy atmosphere, come here. Amazing well thought out dishes from start to finish and very attentive staff. I'm surprised it's only garnered 1 Michelin Star. We had visited the restaurant before it...
review_full: If you want to go on a culinary adventure in an unpretentious and cozy atmosphere, come here. Amazing well thought out dishes from start to finish and very attentive staff. I'm surprised it's only garnered 1 Michelin Star.  We had visited the restaurant before it gained its Michelin rating and were impressed with the innovative dishes coupled with impeccable service. Each dish was beautifully presented and explained by the staff. Note they offered this in both English or Spanish. They even remembered us from our first visit. Your glass was never empty and your server(s) were always close at hand.  Compared to other (1-3) Michelin star restaurants in Madrid this is by far the best overall dinning experience. While it does come with a healthy price tag it's worth every penny. We have been to other starred restaurants and vowed to never go back. Granted it's about the food but if it's served by angry and hurried Oompa Loompa /clock work orange looking staff throwing cutlery down at the table, I'll pass no matter how many stars and how famous the chef is.  We requested to be seated in view of the kitchen to watch the food preparation. On nights Diego is in the kitchen it's a treat to see the maestro at work.  Being our second time around (not our last), you can let your server know what you do and don't want. They even suggest if you have a special occasion to let them know, they will be happy to help ensure you enjoy your visit.  I look forward to returning soon!

title_review: A great spot for a bit of tapas and a drink in Madrid
review_preview: Popped in the H10 Bar after having a look at the menu outside while walking around the side streets. Well kept small bar with extremely friendly and happy staff who made us (a party of 5 including a small child) feel very welcome. We ordered...
review_full: Popped in the H10 Bar after having a look at the menu outside while walking around the side streets. title_review: Excellent-- and VERY gluten free friendly
review_preview: We picked this restaurant mainly because half of my family (3 of 6 people) are celiac and cannot eat gluten. After restaurants in the USA thinking that serving a hamburger and then having you take off the regular bun counts as GF friendly, this place...
review_full: We picked this restaurant mainly because half of my family (3 of 6 people) are celiac and cannot eat gluten. After restaurants in the USA thinking that serving a hamburger and then having you take off the regular bun counts as GF friendly, this place was a breath of fresh air. There are separate gluten free menus, 26 of their 29 tapas can be made GF--with GF bread, not just breadless, the gluten free tapas come on special colored plates, the staff announces clearly which plates arriving have gluten and don't, they had gluten free bread service, AND they brought apertivos and a dessert to the table that were all GF. The service was excellent, especially for Spanish standards, as well as informed about gluten free necessities. All of us, including those of us who ate the regular tapas, loved everything that was served. Definitely recommend for anyone, but especially for anyone with a wheat intolerance or celiac disease.

title_review: Pure Theatre in a relaxed setting. Perfection
review_preview: I am not sure how to do justice to such a wonderful experience in a short review however, i will try to outline the reasons why i think this is a absolute must experience. The restaurant whilst not easy to find is beautifully laid out...
review_full: I am not sure how to do justice to such a wonderful experience in a short review however, i will try to outline the reasons why i think this is a absolute must experience.  The restaurant whilst not easy to find is beautifully laid out inside and in unusual in the Michelin experience sense in that it is very welcoming as are the DStage team.  It is worth arriving slightly ahead of your meal to start to draw in the ambience and relax, prior to your first introduction to the meal. The first course was which was a sublime cockle was presented to us at the bar on top of a bed of Konbu and with smoke from dry ice.  After we had finished our cocktail we decided to go for the 14 Course Menu option and also with drinks pairing. This turned out to be a good an interesting choice.  We were then moved to Kitchen where our Red Prawn ceviche was prepared in front of us by one of the chefs. Tasty but importantly starts to engage you with the restaurant and what they are doing here.  We moved to our table which i was pleased to be in front of the kitchen pass, so we could see the kitchen in operation. Fascinating.  No menu is presented to you until after your meal, deliberately as some of the dishes are deliberately set to trick the senses - that definitely worked and added to the experience.  i have attached pictures of many of the courses with this review so i will note attempt to describe each dish. This is pointless anyway given the changing menu.  All of the 14 dishes were perfectly presented by an expert, knowledgeable and friendly team, who made us feel very much at home. All of the food was delicious and by the end of the meal we had been taken on a complete culinary journey added by the drinks parings.  Even the music being played lightly in the background was unexpected / Springsteen, Ramones, largely 70-80's stuff . different but happens to be what like.  I can't complement enough the quality of the service, the ladies who attended to us were wonderful, friendly and knowledgeable.  At 118 Euro per head in my view this is more that good value given the quality of the experience and ranks in my top 5 favourite meals of all time and very close to the top of those 5.  Brilliant

Everything was a fantastic experience starting with the appetizer at the bar and some beers . Then we were taken into the main dining room which was large but cosy and started the 10 courses with Ceviche. I will not reveal the rest but it was fantastic including the two deserts. Some plates were really extraordinary such as the octopus. We had a little issue with one of them (the meat) but very well compensated! We had a funny bottle of wine (gallon as y focas) from Mallorca and it was another pleasant surprise. If you want a red wine with body yet light woody and earthy notes ask for it. You will love it just like the rest. Check some of the pictures. Enviado desde mi iPhone

title_review: Loved this place, authentic tapas and excellent staff
review_preview: Following on from a visit to see some Flamenco, we dined on Tapas at this great taberna. We had no booking but it was fortunately early enough for us to be accommodated in the downstairs restaurant area.They provided us with a copy of menu...
review_full: Following on from a visit to see some Flamenco, we dined on Tapas at this great taberna. We had no booking but it was fortunately early enough for us to be accommodated in the downstairs restaurant area. They provided us with a copy of menu incorporating and English translation which made life easy for ordering. However, having based our order on three to four dishes each as we might order in the UK when having tapas, the waitress very helpfully recommended we only have two each due to the size and she was completely correct. The portions are excellent value and very substantial. The meat platter we had was especially good and another neighbouring table had the cheese platter which was huge. The waitress who was serving covered all of the approx seven tables in the downstairs restaurant and kept diving up and downstairs with drinks orders and food orders. I don't now how she kept up the pace as she was making me tired just watching but did it all with a smile and was really pleasant throughout to all. Take a visit, we loved everything. It's slightly away from the main tourist spots in the city centre and the value and authenticity of the cuisine are, in my opinion, higher as a result

title_review: Great Atmosphere & beautiful wines...I wish this place was back home!
review_preview: Firstly, I need to start my review off by saying that the gentleman who runs this lovely place was once of the friendliest people we met on our break. This was the first place we went to when we arrived. We quickly checked into our...
review_full: Firstly, I need to start my review off by saying that the gentleman who runs this lovely place was once of the friendliest people we met on our break. This was the first place we went to when we arrived. We quickly checked into our Hotel, unpacked and made our way to here for a stop of lunch. We ordered a beer each and some gorgeous tapas. It was only about 1pm but it was already getting busy. (There is an option to sit downstairs but we loved sitting at the bar and taking it all in!) We then wanted to try a red wine each, and the owner asked us what we liked....he simply gave us a red wine tasting! It was brilliant, we sampled about 4 and decided on a beautiful roja wine. Best way to start your break! Needless to say, we came back here every night or afternoon for a couple of drinks. It was always always busy and it was such a great atmosphere. My Fiance and I were there on Saturday from about 10.30pm - 2am just sitting, drinking red wine & cava, and enjoying ourselves. We must've had 5/6 glasses of wine/cava each and the bill was only about 20Euros!  I wish this place was back in my hometown - I would never leave!!

The lentils with duck had cassoulet-like depth of flavour. Another favourite was the pork cheek with green beans and mashed potatoes. Washed everything down with a half litre of rosado.

review_preview: My wife and I had a fantastic meal here on a Sunday evening. The place was very busy when we initially arrived but they found us a small space at the bar for a few drinks and some pinchos. Once we managed to get a...
review_full: My wife and I had a fantastic meal here on a Sunday evening. The place was very busy when we initially arrived but they found us a small space at the bar for a few drinks and some pinchos.  Once we managed to get a seat, we had a variety of delightful wine and tapas. Our personal favorites were the oxtail (rabo de torro), morcilla & egg and the pork, apple and onion on toast (can't remember its name). For two, i'd recommend about two pinchos and one tapas from the menu. But if you're hungry, it's all great! Would highly recommend you drop in for a couple of drinks and tapas regardless of whether it's busy or not!

review_preview: My wife and I visited Casa Lucas on the whim on a Friday night and found that no tables were available; fortunately for us, we were able to obtain two seats at the counter.  Within the 1/2 hour, the place was buzzing with activity; many...
review_full: My wife and I visited Casa Lucas on the whim on a Friday night and found that no tables were available; fortunately for us, we were able to obtain two seats at the counter. Within the 1/2 hour, the place was buzzing with activity; many more customers were standing behind us and ordering from where they stood. The ambience in Casa Lucas was awesome and it was certainly was great to be part of this great atmosphere. Service was excellent and very professional and certainly very prompt considering the number of customers in the place. My wife and I shared a bottle of the Crianza Rioja red wine and we enjoyed a good number of tapas to include the alella: soy sauce chicken with onion and corn mousse with sesame oil; tomato salad with goat cheese, oregano and basil; and croquettes with ham and mushrooms. This place definitely gets a great recommendation from me.

review_preview: Highly recommended in TripAdvisor, this small tapas space in La Latina (in itself a mass of many such options) was a hit. It seems quite popular with locals as well as visitors. While there were many tempting, obviously popular stops in this part of Madrid,...
review_full: Highly recommended in TripAdvisor, this small tapas space in La Latina (in itself a mass of many such options) was a hit. It seems quite popular with locals as well as visitors. While there were many tempting, obviously popular stops in this part of Madrid, and lots of options for some tapas "hopping" we preferred to stay put and enjoy. We started at the bar, chatting with the bartenders as we were without reservation, but were quickly placed at a table when it became available. There were many classics on the tapas list, but many with a twist such as the fish based "albondigas" meatballs. Our bottle of Verdejo white wine worked well through our plates including a beautiful vegetable terrine garnished with a large shrimp, chicken with salso dressing, roasted bonito as well as the albondigas. Our plateds came at a relaxing pace but we never felt neglected by the friendly wait staff.
